PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-Pursuant to standing order 164, a letter is tabled from the Leader of the Government in the Senate relating to the order of the Senate of 10 September 1991 requiring the tabling of a tape-recording.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

(a) notes the refusal of the Government to comply with the direction contained in the Senate's resolution of Tuesday, 10 September 1991 to lay on the Table of the Senate the tape recording of the discussions held on 4 September 1991 between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and representatives of conservationist groups;
(b) further notes that this refusal to lay the tape on the Table is not based on any claim of executive privilege;

(c) is of the opinion that, subject only to reasonable claims of executive privilege, both Houses of Parliament are fully entitled to scrutinise and demand accountability for all aspects of executive behaviour;
(d) notes with great concern the Government's apparent belief that it is not accountable to the people of Australia through the Parliament;
(e) accordingly, censures the Government for its unjustified failure to comply with the Senate's resolution of 10 September 1991; and
(f) calls upon the Government to comply with the resolution of the Senate this day.

For the benefit of honourable senators who would not have notice of the details of the letter of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, which was given to the Clerk yesterday in reply to the order of the Senate, I will read that letter. He writes:
Dear Mr Evans

I refer to your letter of 10 September regarding the order agreed to by the Senate yesterday relating to the tape recording of discussions held between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and representatives of the conservationist groups.
I have noted the text of the order and advise the Senate that the Government will not be tabling the tape recording to which it refers.
I would point out, however, that the Prime Minister today read to the House of Representatives a transcript of the relevant part of the recording, a copy of which is attached.
Attached to that letter is a quote as follows, which claims to be a transcript extract from peak conservationist organisations meeting dated 4 September 1991:

I've really outlined the sort of structure of the EPA,-and where that's going. I'll just go into the intergovernmental agreement. The first draft, let me tell you about, the intergovernmental agreement-as you know has emerged basically from the Prime Minister's initiative with the States and it is really crass politics, at the lowest common denominator-it is all about mainly the people who are involved in it are not the environment Ministers or their departments, they're Premiers and the bottom line for them all this is the bucks, the big dollars. They would sell their mothers for a few bucks and so the bottom line of much of this negotiation is what we-if they get what they want on transport and housing in terms of untied grants and social serv . . . security they would give us anything, if they don't they're going to make our lives a misery and that's not so very satisfactory but that's the harsh reality of it.

That is the Government's answer to the order of the Senate that it lay before the Senate a certain tape-recording. In other words, the Government refuses, and it refuses without giving any reason. There has been no claim of Crown privilege and no claim that it is a matter of national security, that it is Cabinet in confidence, that it is commercial in confidence, or whatever. It is just a blatant refusal to comply with the order of the Senate.

I would not be at all surprised if certain Government Ministers with a reasonably long memory pricked up their ears when I read my motion earlier. They would realise that it is very much in the same terms as a motion moved in 1982 by Senator Gareth Evans when he was shadow Attorney-General. At that time apparently Senator Gareth Evans believed that the Executive was responsible to the Parliament and that the Senate was fully entitled to scrutinise and demand accountability for all aspects of Executive behaviour.

One might wonder what has changed. What has changed is simply power. Senator Gareth Evans is now in power, and his attitude to the responsibility of the Executive to the Parliament has changed. It is not politically expedient for the Government to provide this tape because it could be politically embarrassing, so it simply disregards the order of the Senate. That is unsatisfactory, and in my submission this Senate has no alternative, therefore, but to move this censure motion.

It is undoubtedly an important issue, and I will get to it in a moment. However, the question of new federalism, to which the tapes relate, is also important. There is a feeling by some that perhaps the issue at stake, other than that of the responsibility of the Executive to the Parliament, is not of the same consequence as some of the previous orders that have been made over the years. That is not so. We all know that, in a situation where there are about one million Australians unemployed, this country requires major structural reform.

One area of structural reform that everyone accepts is the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States, so that there can be a more efficient administration in both. It has been promoted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and we accept that. If, however, a senior Minister of the Crown says to conservation groups that the Prime Minister is not serious, that the Prime Minister is simply engaging in a political game, that he is simply engaging in crass politics, that is a serious matter because it demonstrates to the people of Australia that this Government is not serious about restructuring the relationship between the States and the Commonwealth in the way it claims that it desires to do. Therefore, the determination by Minister Kelly, as she put to these conservation leaders, that the Prime Minister is about crass politics is a very serious matter.

We are entitled to be concerned because we have on the record so many examples where t his Prime Minister, despite there being one million people unemployed in this country, still believes that he has some God-given right to rule and that he is beyond reproach and beyond question. That should never be allowed to occur. In recent times we have had examples of how cynically he regards the Australian people, no better demonstrated than by the conspiracy between him and Mr Keating to deceive the Australian people at the last election. He lied to the Australian people about their intentions as to who would remain Prime Minister after the election.

We are entitled to be concerned. The Australian people are entitled to be concerned because they have had it demonstrated time and time again that this Prime Minister will play whatever political tricks are necessary to remain in government. Here it appears that he is playing another one, because Minister Kelly advised senior conservation leaders that this new federalism is simply a game of crass politics. That is the way it was interpreted by a number of the major conservation leaders present at the meeting. There is one simple way in which the matter can be resolved forever, and that is by the Government doing the right thing-putting the tape on the table and letting the people of Australia have the opportunity to peruse it.

That is all that is being asked. One must wonder again and again why the Government will not comply with that requirement. What is unreasonable about the people of Australia being entitled to hear the tape and determine who is telling the truth: the leaders of the conservation movement who have been defamed by Minister Kelly, or Minister Kelly? Why is she continuing to refuse to do that, to clarify the matter and let the people make a judgment? One can only suspect the reason.

Apart from the important question of the merits of the case, there is the even more important question of this Government's decision blatantly and deliberately to undermine the democratic structure by rejecting the request of the Senate to table this document. As I said, this is an arrogant Government which puts itself above the responsibility that it has to the people, through the Parliament. Ministers are not directly elected by the people. It is the Parliament that is elected. The safeguard is the right of the Parliament to pass orders and for the Executive to comply with such orders. This is an unquestioned principle of the Constitution which, as I said, Senator Evans was pleased to propound in this place in 1982. It is a principle which this Government follows when it is politically expedient for it to do so. To this Government, such a matter is a nuisance. The Parliament itself is a nuisance-it is a distraction. But we will never allow that to be the case. The Senate has passed its order; and that order of the Senate must be complied with.

When the Executive assumes an authority beyond that of the Parliament-that is, those members directly elected by the people-a cornerstone of our constitutional democracy is threatened. That is why the refusal to comply with an order of the Senate is in fact a rarity. You might be interested to know, Mr President, that over 20 orders have been passed by the Senate. On only two occasions was the order not complied with. The Government should take into account why, with only two exceptions since Federation, governments normally have complied with such orders. They do so because they recognise that they owe a responsibility to the Parliament. They recognise that if they disregard the Parliament they will be undermining a cornerstone of our democracy.

Over the years there has been a whole range of orders covering all sorts of matters. The first one in 1924 related to forest products. Another in 1931 related to correspondence between the then Government and the Commonwealth Bank. Another in 1931 related to correspondence between the Labor Party and the then Acting Prime Minister. Again in 1931 there was an order relating to correspondence in respect of Jervis Bay. I will not read them all. But the point I want to make is that the orders relate to a range of different issues covering matters of varying importance. Whether they go to the most vital matter of national interest or otherwise, the practice of government has been to accept that the structure of the Constitution will work only if it respects the dignity of the Parliament-if it respects and duly complies with the orders of the Parliament.

As I have said, there have been only two exceptions to the orders being complied with-one in 1975 and the other in 1982. In 1975 the Senate called before it departmental officers to answer questions relating to the Khemlani loan affair. Those departmental officers claimed crown privilege. An impasse developed and the matter was never resolved. There was then a double dissolution, an election was held and the then Government was defeated.

The other instance was in 1982. As I indicated a moment or two ago, Senator Evans brought an action before the Senate which related to the production of legal opinions that concerned bottom of the harbour cases. In the first instance, the Government of the day complied with that by tabling a whole series of documents that Senator Evans required. But it was not prepared to do so in the case of certain legal opinions because it claimed that they had crown privilege. I remind the Senate that, according to Senator Button's letter, there is no issue of crown privilege in what this Government has said today. There is no claim of any justification at all. As I said, in 1982 the Government of the day claimed crown privilege in relation to legal documents and legal opinions. That is not an unusual course of action.

Mr President, you might like to know what Senator Evans said about the responsibility of government to the Parliament in these instances. I refer to the Hansard of 8 September 1982 in which Senator Evans said that it was important that these documents be tabled to enable the Parliament and the community as a whole to form its own view. This is exactly what we have said today. He went on:

The only way that blame can begin to be established and rightly located is by the tabling of all the information, all the relevant documents, that will enable an even better judgment to be made of the situation than we have been able to make so far.
He continued:
I believe that access to these documents will enable, if not the whole truth to emerge finally, at least us to get some distance down that particular track.
The Senate will be surprised to learn that Senator Evans said:
We have chosen the path of moderation and reasonableness.

In that instance, it was regarded by Senator Evans to be both moderate and reasonable that the Senate should expect those documents, in the same way that it is more than moderate and reasonable that the Senate be entitled to this tape in the public interest today. He continued, and repeated time and time again-occasionally he can be repetitious:
. . . in order that we and the public at large can better form a view as to where the blame lies, where the merits lie and where the truth lies in this matter . . . the documents must be produced.

Mr President, exactly the same position exists today. The Senate is entitled to this document in this instance. Papers, by practice of the Senate, have included tapes. It is in the public interest that the public be entitled to learn where the truth lies in this particular instance.

What did Senator Evans do at the end of that process when he was unsuccessful in getting those documents? He moved a censure motion, as I said, in terms almost identical to what the Opposition is moving today. He was overtaken in that instance by an election. The issue was never finally resolved. What we demand today is exactly as Senator Evans demanded in 1982.

The Senate made an order two days ago. The Government has failed to comply with that order. It has made no claim of Executive privilege. Even if the Government had made a claim of Executive privilege, we would, consistent with our long held view and consistent with the authorities as contained in Odgers, say that it is ultimately for the Senate to decide whether the stand of Executive privilege should be upheld or not. This, as I said, was simply an arrogant refusal of this Government to comply.

The Government has tabled part of a transcript which clearly can be read in exactly the way the conservationists have said it should be read. The letters tabled by Minister Kelly in the House of Representatives yesterday did not contradict that point of view. It was the view of four conservationists that Minister Kelly was saying that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was indulging in nothing more than crass politics. We heard it also from the spokesman for Greenpeace this morning-the same interpretation of what Minister Kelly said. Of course, it would not be surprising if that is what she was saying because she supports Mr Keating in the leadership contest. It is in her interests to undermine the position of the Prime Minister.

As I said a moment ago, the only way the people of Australia can know for certain is by listening to the tape. If Minister Kelly is innocent there is one simple way in which she can demonstrate it. While she refuses, one must suspect that she has no faith in the Prime Minister's federalism initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not really putting your heart into this.

—Senator Faulkner may have no interest in the Prime Minister's federalism initiative-I do not know which side he is on in that particular debate. The Government should cease to put political expediency beyond its requirement to comply with an order of the Parliament. It should cease to put its political survival beyond that cornerstone of the Constitution which is so important. In other words, it should comply with the order, stop this nonsense, produce the tape and let the people of Australia make their own decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting this motion, and supporting it very strongly.
—Demanding tapes of private meetings-disgraceful!

—I appreciate the interjection from Senator Collins. If he had been in the chamber the other day he would know that we rehearsed very adequately the reasons why this was not a private meeting. This, indeed, was very much a public meeting. It was a meeting between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and representatives of peak councils which represent many tens of thousands, possibly hundreds of thousands, of Australians. It goes also very much to the matter of whether it was a private meeting or not that here we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), not the Minister for the environment, negotiating with the State governments in relation to the management of the Australian environment. It is a very important area of decision making.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons we believe that the public have a right to know that the public interest supersedes any considerations that this was indeed a private meeting. We are particularly pleased that the Opposition's motion is aimed fairly and squarely at the Government, and not in this case at Minister Kelly. We accept the arguments that Senator Hill has advanced in relation to privilege and the clauses in his motion which precede clause 5 censuring the Government for its unjustified failure to comply with the Senate resolution of 10 September.

The letter before us from Senator Button is an incredibly arrogant letter. Clearly, he is speaking on behalf of the Government. He is not speaking just as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, but also as a very important Government representative. He is saying that the Government simply refuses an order of the Senate. I repeat the claim made by Senator Hill a few moments ago that this Senate is composed of people directly elected by the people of Australia. We are a representative chamber. We are responsible directly to the people of Australia. This Government, which is not directly elected by the people of Australia, is thumbing its nose at the directly elected chamber of the Senate and refusing to release the tape-recording.
Senator Hill has already reflected on the words of the very partial transcript that has been released by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —How edited is it?

—It is a tiny fragment of what must have been a much longer dialogue between the Minister and the representatives of those peak conservation bodies. It is quite clear that a partial transcript cannot give one a flavour of the whole dialogue that occurred at that meeting. Moreover, it is also quite clear that depending upon where the emphasis is put on these words, they are open to the interpretation either that the State Premiers and State governments were indulging in crass politics or, indeed, that the Prime Minister himself was engaging in crass politics and that the whole process of new federalism was an exercise in crass politics.

SPEECH.PARA: As the words are punctuated in the partial transcript that we have, they read:
. . . basically from the Prime Minister's initiative with the States and it is really crass politics,-
The clear reading of those words, in my view, is that Minister Kelly was reflecting on the Prime Minister's moves in this area of new federalism.

As honourable senators will know from yesterday's debate, the Democrats are particularly concerned about the substantive issue of the protection of the Australian environment under this pattern of new federalism. Yesterday, senators learned-almost certainly from Senator Richardson's remarks-that the Government is moving into an area of changing the management of the Australian environment; that that move is being led by the Prime Minister and his officers; and that Minister Kelly and the Department of the Environment have no handle on that process at all. Surely that issue is of vital concern to the Australian people. They have a right to know what is going on and how their environment is to be protected.

As I indicated in my speech yesterday, all the recent surveys of Australian public opinion indicate a very high level of concern by the Australian public for a better protection of the Australian environment. All those surveys indicate that the public want the Federal Government to use its powers more comprehensively-powers which indeed it has used in the past-but it seems from the draft of the intergovernmental agreement which we already have, the fourth draft, that the Federal Government is moving to tie its own hands and not exercise those powers in the ways in which both it and the Opposition have in the past.

That is a matter of public interest. That is a matter which should be rightly brought before the Senate chamber. That is a matter on which the tape recording of the meeting between Minister Kelly and the peak environment groups is relevant. That is a matter which goes to the heart of the question of whether the Government has a right to withhold that information from the properly elected Senate. Accordingly, we very strongly support this motion moved by the Opposition.

Part 6 of the motion calls upon the Government to comply with the resolution of the Senate, and we note the arrogance of this Government in not having complied with that resolution of the Senate; the arrogance of Minister Button in writing that very terse note to the Senate in which he simply refuses, as the motion before us says, to provide any substantive grounds as to why that tape should not be provided to the Senate. Again, as Senator Hill has said, even if grounds had been provided, it would be up to the Senate to determine whether those grounds were adequate, legal and justifiable or not. But no grounds whatsoever have been provided in this very brief and terse note from Minister Button. Accordingly, we have very great pleasure in supporting this motion moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion and congratulate Senator Coulter on a most interesting and convincing contribution. I have disagreed with Senator Coulter many times in the past, but I agree totally with what he had to say today. I would like to deal very briefly with some very significant points.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it must be recognised that what appears to be an inconsequential matter of whether a tape recording reveals that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Hon. Ros Kelly, described Mr Hawke's cooperative federalism as crass politics may not be regarded as a terribly serious matter, I suppose, by those people who are accustomed to Ministers of this Government telling deliberate, total falsehoods. There is nothing unusual about it. I suppose some people are asking: why are we getting so excited about yet another deliberate lie from a Government Minister? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has admitted to lying, so some people might say that there is not much significance in this matter. But there is, because in the Government's determination not to allow the truth to emerge it has determined to confront the Senate and to deny the authority of an elected parliament. This is not the House of Representatives challenging the Senate; this is the Executive Government challenging the Senate. We have to ask: why is it so significant? Why is Kellygate of such massive importance that the Government is prepared to challenge the Senate?

The principle of privacy was raised in a quaint interjection by Senator Collins. It followed the nonsensical speech Senator Richardson made the other day on this topic. There is one vital matter that Senator Richardson and the Government have to face up to: the principle of privacy-a very important principle, indeed-is totally breached if a private meeting is held and a party to that private meeting then misrepresents what happened at that meeting to the public. That breaches totally the principle of privacy. That is what this Minister did. She breached the principle of privacy which she now seeks to hide behind by telling complete untruths about what happened there.

The conservationists who were there have in a united way revealed the extent to which Mrs Kelly misled the public about what happened at that meeting. It was not just a question about crass politics, but it was also a question about objections; it was on another ground. There has been no denial by Mrs Kelly that what the conservationists have now said is absolutely right; that she breached the privacy of that meeting by telling untruths about the extent of opposition from the conservation movement to the draft of that proposal, the Prime Minister's proposal. The privacy having been breached, the Minister is now desperately trying to clothe herself with the protection that she herself destroyed.

This nonsense that Senator Richardson has been going on about, the sanctity of privacy, is absolute and utter bunkum. Apparently it is all right for the Government's Minister to have a meeting in private and then tell lies about the outcome and not be prepared to put up with the other people who were at that meeting saying, `No, that is not what happened at all'. That totally removes from the discussion this phoney issue of it being a private matter.

What is absolutely central to this particular matter is that when the Prime Minister agreed to reveal a transcript of a small section of 30 seconds out of three hours of the meeting, it was significant that the other people who were there have not come forward to say, `My memory must have been wrong'. The Government did not produce that in the House of Representatives yesterday. People have not resiled, as I understand it, from their position. If that is so, it underlines the question one must ask about how real, how accurate, how correct, that 30 seconds is in conveying what really happened in those three hours of the meeting.

That extract is capable of being interpreted as total support for what the conservationists are saying. It is capable of being interpreted in lots of ways. It is totally incoherent. If it is an expression of the Minister's thinking, God help the environment and Australia. It is full of sentences that begin by being somewhat vague and end by being even vaguer.

It is important to note that Senator Robert Ray demonstrated to us very strongly the day before yesterday why there is a huge difference between a transcript and a tape. He was even prepared to accuse me of lying when I inadvertently said that someone from the Prime Minister's office had heard a little bit of the tape when, in fact, that person had read a little bit of the transcript. On our side we assume those to be the same in terms of substance. Theoretically there is no difference. As far as we are concerned there is no difference between a transcript and a tape because they are matters of substance that are the same.

Senator Robert Ray does not think so. He accused me of lying by saying that someone had listened to the tape instead of saying that the person had read the transcript. As far as the Labor Party is concerned, this clearly indicates that there is a huge difference between a tape and a transcript because transcripts can either be fiddled with or a tiny extract, like 30 seconds, can be taken from a tape which distorts the meaning which would be evident when one listened to the tape as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has something been deleted from it-some expletives?

—Senator Macdonald's interjection about something being deleted raises questions about this Kellygate affair. To what extent are these Nixon-type tapes, anyway? Why is the Government not revealing them? We have already seen, by allowing the transcript to come out, that there is stuff that is clearly offensive to the State Premiers that undermines-and deliberately so-the Prime Minister's relationship with the States, which is essential if his policy of cooperative federalism is to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Kelly's discussion about the State Premiers with the conservationists clearly does nothing to help the Prime Minister's relationship with them on this sensitive issue. It is aimed at undermining the Prime Minister's relationship with the Premiers. We can see that from the response of the State Premiers. `The emperor strikes back', said Mr Greiner. Labor Premiers are refusing to give a response to it because they are not going to credit it as something worthy of a response.

If the full tape is not to be revealed, I wonder how many other insults are in it. I wonder how many expletives have been deleted. I wonder how Nixonian Kellygate really is. In the end, I should let the Government know that the Nixon tapes eventually did undo President Nixon. I wonder how undone Mrs Kelly will be when this tape eventually emerges.
There is no doubt from the tape that Mrs Kelly's views of Mr Hawke's cooperative federalism are clearly antagonistic, no matter how one interprets her comment, and I quote from the transcript:

The first draft, let me tell you, the intergovernmental agreement-as you know has emerged basically from the Prime Minister's initiative with the States and it is really crass politics, at the lowest common denominator-

Full stop. The situation that has been created has been created by the Prime Minister. It has emerged `basically from the Prime Minister's initiative . . . it is really crass politics'. In other words, as to the system the Prime Minister has developed, Mrs Kelly now says, `Oh, I only meant that they would misuse it'. Even if we take her interpretation of this messy bit of semantics, she is saying that the Prime Minister has been foolish enough to create a hopeless situation in which the Premiers can play crass politics at the expense of the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Either way it is bad.

—Even if one takes her interpretation, it is undermining the Prime Minister. As Senator Hill says, either way she has set out-and it is now evident-to undermine the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister's policy in relation to the environment. By way of conclusion, this impression is reinforced today by the latest Kellygate bit, where a representative of Greenpeace says that Mrs Kelly had told meetings he had attended that new federalism contradicted strong environmental policy. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . she considers that new federalism and environment protection are contradictory . . .
He said that that was very clear from the meetings he had attended. This has been a consistent pattern of undermining by Mrs Kelly.

TALK.START.PARA: —She has rejected the Prime Minister.

—As Senator Hill says, she has consistently rejected the Prime Minister. She regards her policies as in conflict with the Prime Minister's. She is part of the campaign to destroy the Prime Minister and she is using the environment as yet another weapon in that campaign to get rid of the Prime Minister and replace him with Mr Keating.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite frankly, she can use in her internal battles what methods she likes. When those methods come out into the public arena, when they cause concern and in fact upset a large part of the population, when they create doubt in the minds of people as to what the Government's policy really is-is it the Kelly policy or is it the Hawke policy-then the Parliament and the people have a right to know what really happened at that expletive-deleted meeting.

It is a disgrace that this Government is prepared to protect this Minister because of these internal dissensions and because of the need to make certain that the waters remain as unruffled as possible. If the Prime Minister did what he should do and sacked this Minister, there would be repercussions in the battle for the leadership. There is no basis of principle on which this Government is keeping this secret. The Government has something to hide. It must reveal it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest to the contributions this morning because I have been trying to work out what prompts this performance. I suspect, having listened to the last couple of contributions, that it is not so difficult to work out. Yesterday there were some significant events. The first, I think, was the House of Representatives refusing a motion of Mr Chaney's to release the tape. So the House of Representatives took a position directly contrary to the Senate.
—On the basis of principle, of course.
—No, I simply state a fact: the House of Representatives rejected a motion to produce the tape.
—Who are you trying to kid?

—I am not trying to kid anybody. That is on the record, but Senator Newman does not believe that. I feel sorry for Senator Newman, but then again I often have. If one goes past that, two other events yesterday, which were much more important, prompted the Opposition into action.

SPEECH.PARA: The first was Question Time. Every report of Question Time suggests that Dr Hewson and Mr Chaney were very much the losers; they did very poorly. The Press Gallery sat there and watched but did something that the Liberals really could not forgive: the Press Gallery asked some questions of Mr Chaney, the reaction to which suggests that yesterday was probably the low point of Mr Chaney's career. All the momentum that the Opposition was allegedly building up disappeared yesterday. It did very badly indeed. So here today the Opposition is trying to concoct a crisis. Sadly for those opposite, there just is not one, and no number of speeches can create it.

First, we should deal with the legalities. We are not here dealing with a question of constitutional law but merely a question of constitutional practice. We have the Senate demanding the release of a tape by a person in another place and we have the House of Representatives refusing to pass the same motion. I quote from Erskine and May. I think the quote is pretty clear. It says:

The leading principle which appears to pervade all the proceedings between the Houses of Parliament is that there shall subsist a perfect equality between them, and that they shall be, in every respect, totally independent one of the other.
Here is the crux--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixty-six plus 44-what does that add up to?
—I thought you failed law.
—What about the relationship with the Executive?
—Order! The speakers from the Opposition were heard in relative silence.
—Mr Deputy President, I object to that; it is just nonsense.
—They were heard in relative silence.
—Oh, ha, ha!

—Senator Baume, you will come to order. If you want to be insolent, I will deal with you. The members on my left were heard in relative silence-not in silence-so I ask that the same consideration be given to the Minister.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It relates to the requirement of the Chair to deal, as I understand it, impartially with the proceedings of the chamber. My point is that you, Mr Deputy President, had to consistently call to order particularly Senator Faulkner during my speech. As a result of that, some order did descend later in the speech, but for the bulk of the time I was subjected to non-stop interjections. I ask you to review the comments you have just made.
—I indicated when I spoke that members of the Opposition were heard in relative silence. I call the Minister.
—I was coming to the crux of this quote from Erskine May:

SPEECH.PARA: Hence it is that neither House can claim, much less exercise, any authority over a member of the other-

So while the Senate can pass censure motions against the Government and demand that Mrs Kelly produce the tape, there is no way that it can enforce those resolutions. What we are indulging in here is not an issue of constitutional law or constitutional practice but, rather, to quote a phrase oft heard in the last few days, an exercise in crass politics-the crassest of politics.

I quote from the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review. One would not refer to the Australian Financial Review as a socialist rag or a mouthpiece of the Australian Labor Party, but its editorial does have some interesting points. It says:

But by blunting and repelling the Opposition's main attack, the Government has placed itself in a position to turn the attack back, and to argue that the Opposition has indulged in a trivial and time-wasting pursuit. . . . But to concentrate, as the Opposition has over the past week, on what has turned out to be a bit of colourful language by one politician talking about other politicians, and to make the ridiculous suggestion that there was a real constitutional issue at stake, is plain silly.

That sums up this issue. The citizens of Australia must regard this as one of the great yawns of our time. I am particularly disappointed in Senator Coulter's contribution, because Senator Coulter appears to have taken a position on whether this meeting was private which runs contrary to almost every person who has attended that meeting or the other meetings of the peak councils during the last four years. As the Minister who presided over them for three years, I can assure Senator Coulter, the Senate and anyone else who may be listening, if they are unfortunate enough to be doing so, that those meetings have always been private. They were structured in that way in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Mrs Kelly make them public?

—Mrs Kelly did not make them public. The difficulty Senator Coulter and all Opposition senators face in this matter is that there is no question not only that they have been private in the past but also that they remain so. If we want to look for the sources of that, they are not too hard to find. Firstly, I quote from Don Henry, the Director of the World Wide Fund for Nature:

SPEECH.PARA: World Wide Fund for Nature Australia believes that the privacy of Peak Conservation Group Meetings should be respected. It has been our understanding in the past that no formal transcript of the meeting has been made, rather, that a listing of action points from the meeting is developed.

We have no doubt where the World Wide Fund for Nature stands on the question. If one then looks at the Australian Council of National Trusts, we have a letter signed by Duncan Marshall of that organisation and by Harry Barber for the Conservation Council of Victoria which, in part, says:
The Australian Council of National Trusts and Conservation Council of Victoria write to support a call for all parties to respect the privacy of Peak Conservation Group meetings.
The above groups are participants in Peak meetings. These meetings occur regularly and involve discussions with Ministers, Shadow Ministers and other parliamentarians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government gave them $84,000 last year and $90,000 this year.

—I would be surprised if even someone like Senator Campbell thought the National Trust was not worthy of support. Then again he may think that. If he has that view, I am quite happy for him to express it. He has gone silent. Is that not a shock and a surprise? There is then correspondence here from the Australian Conservation Foundation, in which Phillip Toyne expresses his strong support for the continuation of those meetings to be conducted on a private and confidential basis.

SPEECH.PARA: But the matter does not end there. Senator Coulter really has placed himself at odds with the conservation movement on this question. I quote Rosie Crisp, the Coordinator of the Queensland Conservation Council, who of course was a participant in the meeting:

Well obviously the meeting that was held with the Minister and conservationists was a private meeting . . . these are regular meetings that are held with the Minister and the discussion is very open and honest and frank and it is a private discussion.

There are not simply one or two people saying this, but a whole raft of people saying that it is a private meeting. As the person who convened them for three years, I assure honourable senators that that was always the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very effectively.

—Yes, very effectively. I am glad Senator Faulkner said that. The important thing is that in my time as Minister there was only one leak from the meetings. The person responsible was from the Wilderness Society and got as big a serve from the rest of the conservation movement as he got from me. It did not happen again. The privacy of those meetings was respected for all of those three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently in this exercise of crass politics, there is a suggestion that Mrs Kelly has in some way-I cannot quite understand the way myself-attacked the Prime Minister. If one reads the press this morning, there cannot be any doubt in its mind that the extract from the tape does suggest that she did not attack the Prime Minister but did attack the Premiers. In fact, various newspapers quote the Premiers' reactions to Mrs Kelly's words. The Premiers, from Mr Bannon to Mr Greiner, were not in any doubt about who got criticised, and they have responded as one might expect them to respond if they have been criticised. Let us look at the words of Rodney Falconer on AM on 11 September this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —No relation.

—No, no relation to my colleague. I quote what Rodney Falconer had to say. If we are talking about the Prime Minister being attacked by Mrs Kelly, if this really is some sort of terrible plot which the Government is purporting to protect, I think Rodney Falconer's words are instructive:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that she was quite strongly on that particular issue-
that was the whole of the federalism proposals-
took an official line if you like, a Prime Ministerial line. On some issues she sympathised with us, on others she disagreed.
In fact, he said:
We weren't pleased with the federal line as a whole as represented by Mrs Kelly . . .
The point was that Mrs Kelly's performance at the meeting of the Peak Council of Conservation Groups had been to support--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you heard the tape?

—Of course I have not heard the tape, and I have no intention whatsoever of trying to. Why would I want to hear the tape? The tape is of a private meeting. If good government is to continue, if there is to be any hope for the effectiveness of that government kind of meeting to continue, there has to be some respecting of the privacy of it. These are meetings which have for years--
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
—Come on, Marge.
—I beg your pardon.
—Come on, Marge.
—Senator Bishop, did you have a point of order?
—Mr Deputy President, if the Minister thinks he is being amusing by being insulting, I would ask him to withdraw that remark.
—I have not been insulting at all.
—Indeed, in my view you have.
—I did not hear a remark--
—He was making a disparaging comment in calling me a name that is not my name. I would ask him to withdraw it.
—Is that your point of order?
—No. I ask the Minister to withdraw the remark.

—I seek your guidance, Mr Deputy President. If I have in any way made an unparliamentary remark, then obviously I will withdraw. But there is a reference in the Sydney Morning Herald to Senator Bishop. In fact, it was Senator Collins last night, the man described here as having a waist as big as Kakadu--

—Order! I think it might not be wise to compound anything that has occurred. I heard a remark and I am not quite sure that I regard it as unparliamentary. I did not know where it came from. It certainly came from my right. If Senator Bishop finds the word unparliamentary, I would ask for it to be withdrawn. I think that is the easiest course.
—I withdraw the remark.

—My point of order relates to the fact that we are debating a specific motion relating to the tape which the Senate has ordered be produced and tabled. The Minister has now admitted that he has not heard the tape and he is attempting to defend a tape which he is no longer finding relevant in his address. I ask him to address the subject matter of the motion or cease his contribution to the debate.

—I cannot see any point of order. I think that on a matter involving a censure of the Government it is quite in order for the Minister to range fairly widely. As a matter of fact, I am not sure that he has been ranging too widely.

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order, there has been a recent case of mistaken identity. I certainly did interject a moment ago and referred to Senator Bishop as `Marge'. In the same spirit as Senator Richardson, I withdraw that.
—I thought that might have been the case.

—The whole point that I have sought to make is that it was a private meeting and therefore the tape should not be released. The fact that it is a private meeting means: why would I want to listen to the tape? If it is indeed private, there can be no question on the basis of all the comments of the participants bar one-I will get to that in a moment-that it was a private meeting. If all the participants say so, it is quite extraordinary that here in the Senate there seem to be a whole lot of people with a different view. None has ever been a participant at these meetings or ever will be. None can therefore comment.
—I participated in all the meetings as representative of the Conservation Council of South Australia.
—Not in the last four years.
—Long before you arrived.

—I am quite prepared to say that Senator Coulter has attended some. But I am certain that there is no-one in the Opposition who could ever go near a conservation group, let alone get elected to a position where they finish up at a peak council meeting. No-one over there would ever get the environmental movement to allow them to go near the movement to talk to them or anything else.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —You, Senator Macdonald, are the one on whom Queensland conservation groups are concentrating for your appalling attitude to the environment. I will return to the point; it is only interjections that get me to range from the point.
—I have been to several of them. They know at least that I tell the truth.

—I would love to have a contest. It is clear from all those quotes I read out that two things emerge from that meeting: firstly, all of its participants, except for one person, regard the meeting as private; and, secondly, all of them, bar one again, are making it very clear that Mrs Kelly took the line the Prime Minister has been taking on new federalism. It is the fact that she took that line, that she would not depart from that line, which the conservationists obviously do not like, that caused so much anger and the leaks that finally came from that meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: All of those people do not wish the tape to be produced. The only person who has come out and said that this was not a private meeting was Mr Gilding from Greenpeace, and I note with interest that Senator Baume quoted from him this morning. I had not realised that statements by Greenpeace would become the gospel for the Opposition. Mr Gilding's comments put him at absolute odds with the rest of the participants at that meeting. So, does one out of a dozen equal a majority? I think most Government members would say no.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not make him wrong.
—The word of the other 11 does not make them wrong either. There are so many who can overrule his view and the weight of evidence is so strongly against him that one could not go any other way.
—That does not make him wrong.

—I hope Senator Crane never sits on a jury. Given the word of all those people who attended the meeting, given the history of those meetings as always having been private, one wonders how we get to the stage we are at this morning. We get there for only one reason: the Opposition had a very bad day yesterday. It was given a dreadful time by the gallery. I do not blame Senator Bjelke-Petersen for yawning; I would too. I said it was one of the great yawns of our time. The Opposition got a very bad time yesterday and did very poorly indeed. This censure motion amounts to no more than a stunt that is all about crass politics. It is not about constitutions or law; only about politics.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day the Australian people will be entitled to wonder why the Senate wasted its time on a motion such as this, why all of us had to sit here and go through this when the reality is that there is no power whatsoever to enforce this resolution. The only thing that can be achieved here is yet another debate about whether the tape of a private meeting should be produced when the participants at the meeting, bar one, will say that it should not. I wonder why the Democrats would want to lend themselves to the crass politics in this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson concluded his speech by saying that this Senate has no power to compel the production of the tapes in question. Senator Richardson began his speech by saying that this was a debate not about constitutional law but about constitutional practice. That may well be the case, but this is a debate about a constitutional practice that is honoured by this Government more in the breach than in the observance.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson knows full well that this Senate does have the power to compel the production of these tapes; that the resolution of the Senate passed on Tuesday is a binding resolution. Senator Richardson knows full well that the refusal of this Government to comply with the resolution of the Senate amounts almost to a contempt of this chamber and of the institution of representative government.

For Senator Richardson's benefit, perhaps we might start with the ludicrous argument that this was a private meeting. Is it appropriate that the tape of a meeting should be brought into the public domain? That is the question Senator Richardson asked not only on Tuesday but also today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't be able to talk if you had your hands tied behind your back.

—If Senator West keeps flapping her wings, she might fly away as well and find herself sitting next to the tooth fairy. Perhaps it might not be ordinarily appropriate for a tape of a private meeting to be brought into the public domain. But let us not forget this one fact: the matter in question is already in the public domain. How can anybody honestly say that this was a private meeting when the contents of the meeting-the matter in question-have been spread throughout the newspapers, over radio and television? And this Government has the audacity to come before the Senate and say, `But it is still a private meeting'!

SPEECH.PARA: For Senator Richardson's benefit, I will quote from the Australian. He obviously did not get around to reading the Australian today. Referring to Minister Kelly's refusal to make the tape available on the grounds that it was a private meeting, Glenn Milne said:

Her excuse for not doing so amounted to a legal fiction. Kelly claimed the meeting was private and should remain so. This was a meeting, the contents of which had already been published on the front page of the Weekend Australian, an account that included confirmation by three green representatives present at the September 4 meeting.

It was a meeting that Kelly discussed with the Prime Minister the same morning when he interrupted his racing tips to call her from Sydney's Ramada Renaissance hotel to check what she had actually said.

So much for the argument that it was a private meeting. The matter is in the public domain and it is therefore important, if we are to have any confidence in this Minister, in this Government and in the honour and integrity of the Executive, that the whole of the tape be produced. The questions that now arise go right to the heart of Minister Kelly's ability to discharge her duties as a member of the Executive Government.

Yesterday Senator Richardson also tried the line, contradictory to his first argument, that we could get the tapes under the Freedom of Information Act. This Senate, in passing the Freedom of Information Act, never intended to abrogate its powers under Standing Orders to an item of legislation. The Freedom of Information Act was always supplementary to the powers of the Senate that have remained and remain to this day. In raising that foolish freedom of information argument on Tuesday, Senator Richardson showed what a poor grasp he has of the facts.

As Senator Hill said, there are some 20 precedents of motions calling on the Government to table documents. These are perhaps instructive for Senator Richardson and his colleagues on the other side of the chamber. For example, on 19 March 1931 a resolution was passed requiring the production of all papers in connection with an increase of duty on oregon and, in particular, letters from the secretary to the executive of the South Australian branch of the Labor Party, addressed respectively to the Acting Prime Minister and to the Prime Minister, to be laid upon the table of the Library.

This clearly shows that this Labor Party that occupies the Government benches is trying an old stunt. It is trying to do what it tried to do before; but at least the Labor Party of 1931 had a sense of integrity and decency and knew that it had to comply with an order of the Senate when it was made. This Labor Party, this pathetic excuse for what once may have been a great Party, does not have the integrity, the honesty and the courage to comply with an order of the Senate. It treats this Senate with contempt, and for that it should be condemned. That is why we have moved this censure motion against the Government today.

Of course, Senator Richardson might also be interested to know that in 1982 the Labor Party Opposition asked for the production of papers. Perhaps Senator Richardson may be enlightened to know that his colleague, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), had no difficulties about requiring the production of highly confidential documents-documents which were much more confidential than these because they related to legal advices on pending court cases. Yet, this Government refuses to make available a tape of a meeting, the contents of which are already public, upon the ludicrous argument that the meeting was private. Senator Richardson clearly does not know what he is talking about.

Senator Richardson came into this chamber and selectively quoted from Erskine May's Parliamentary Practice. Senator Richardson said that there was an equality between both Houses of parliament and that neither House could exercise authority over a member of the other House. Erskine May may well say that. But did Senator Richardson tell us what Erskine May said on page 433? No, he did not. For Senator Richardson's information, Erskine May said:
It has been admitted that a document which has been cited-
and goodness knows how many times this document has been cited-
ought to be laid upon the table of the House, if it can be done without injury to the public interests.

I submit that the production of this tape is not only not contrary to the public interest but is directly in promotion of the public interest so that we can see the disgraceful and shameful way in which this Government conducts itself.

Of course, Senator Richardson, in putting the spurious argument that the Senate could not order the Government to produce a document, overlooks the fact that in 1982 his good friend and colleague Senator Evans in fact moved a motion calling upon Senator Chaney, as Minister representing the then Attorney-General, to table documents here in the Senate. Senator Richardson cannot even go back and get it right in regard to what his mate Senator Evans did in 1982.

There is a difference, too, between a member of the House of Representatives and this Government. What the Senate is doing is calling upon the Government to comply with an order of the Senate. Senator Richardson cannot get away with his ludicrous argument that there is some sort of executive privilege. The fact is that the only privilege that this Government can claim is the privilege of its own arrogance in believing that it is not accountable to the people.
The fact is that a very clear case of what is and is not executive privilege was decided by the High Court of Australia in 1978. I refer to the Sankey v. Whitlam case.

TALK.START.PARA: —A famous case.
—Indeed, a very famous case involving another honourable Labor Prime Minister.
—Who said?

—Well, Mr Whitlam did have principles and, if people did not like them, he found others. The High Court ruled in 1978 that documents or portions thereof were not privileged from production unless, of course, the public interest would be harmed by the disclosure of those documents. What harm could be done to the public interest by finding out whether or not Mrs Kelly is a Minister of integrity? I would have thought that if Mrs Kelly were a Minister of integrity, it would be in the public interest to table the documents. But this Government does not think so.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the final word on the matter came from a President of the Senate on 22 November 1978. In relation to the production of documents and the question of executive privilege, he said:
I go no further than to express the view that the Senate would no doubt take the recent High Court judgment into consideration in reaching any decisions.
He also said:
Replying generally, the questions involve matters which are ultimately for the Senate to decide in the regulation of its own proceedings.

It is appropriate for the Senate to decide these matters. It is within the power of the Senate to decide these matters. It is within the power of the Senate to order this disgraceful, dishonest and disgusting Government to comply with the principles of representative government, to comply with the principles of parliamentary duty and to table the tapes that this Senate and the people of Australia demand to know about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is to be expected. It shows that constitutionally the Westminster system under which we operate is a party system, and the reason for that will soon be illustrated. When a vote is taken on this matter I hope that not a single person from this side of the chamber will do anything but vote against it. I hope that all senators the other side of the chamber will be loyal enough to vote with their parties. I would be disappointed if, on an issue of party politics such as this, people did not stand by the party under whose banner they sit in this place. There is no doubt that a motion such as this would be defeated in the other place because the Australian Labor Party--
—It has the numbers.
—As Senator Walters says, it has the numbers. That is absolutely correct.

SPEECH.PARA: So I think it is important, first of all, to understand what this motion is all about. I do not mean to say by that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now I see the constitutional point.

—It is a constitutional point. As Senator Alston knows, constitutionally the party which governs is the one that wins the greatest number of seats in the House of Representatives. There is no doubt that the honourable senator has every ambition in the world-and properly so-to be a Minister--
—On the front or back bench?

—On the front bench-after the next election. I would hope and expect that his colleagues would stay solidly behind him and support him if he got into any difficulties. All I am saying is that that is the reality of this situation.
—The party ahead of the principle-is that what you are saying?

—Well, we are all putting party ahead. In this sort of circumstance-if that is how the honourable senator puts it-everybody does so. Senator Hill says that one puts party ahead of principle. All I am saying is that, as a matter of reality in this chamber and the other place, that is the way the system operates.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of that reality and things being as they are, the situation is that the Senate has passed a motion and made an order which must be treated very seriously. The fact of the matter is that the tapes have not been laid on the table.

There is no doubt in my mind that it is proper in certain circumstances for the Senate and the House of Representatives to make orders for the production of tapes. Everybody has agreed that the public interest is a significant consideration in deciding whether or not a particular tape or a particular piece of evidence should be produced.

There is no doubt that this chamber makes decisions on the basis of what is in the public interest. I would like to give an example of where this chamber in recent times has decided that it would be wrong for people to reveal what went on during a meeting. As a result of the content of a particular meeting being revealed in this chamber, a system has been adopted under which the word `isolated' appears when the recording equipment has been turned off. This situation arose because some time ago Senator Schacht revealed the content of a meeting attended by people who were interested in preserving early life. I would have thought that meeting was a public meeting in the sense that people from all parties were in attendance. Even though the meeting was broadcast over the system, people, in my view properly, took exception to the fact that what was said was revealed in this chamber.

Whether a matter ought to be revealed seems to me to be an issue. In the matter I have just referred to, the other side was saying that the contents of the meeting should not have been revealed, and Senator Chris Schacht-a man of tender emotions, a person very easily hurt-was subject to some criticism which I do not think he has ever recovered from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Barney!

—Senator Herron was not here then. I thought Senator Bjelke-Petersen was quite right in the approach that she took. She said that that sort of thing should not have been revealed to the public without people being told about it. I do not think it matters whether this was a private meeting or a public meeting. The significant thing is that the recording Mrs Kelly made was for her own purpose. It was a confidential tape. I do not think it matters very much whether it is a public meeting or a private meeting. What does matter is whether she recorded that on tape in a confidential manner.
—But it wasn't her. It was a Commonwealth public servant who took it, not her.

—It was for her purposes. Nobody is talking about that. If we take this principle too far, everything will be made open so that all of us on the last day of each of our sittings have to bring in our private diaries about what has happened in this chamber, in party meetings--
—She is a Minister of the Crown doing her job.
—The distinction made by Senator Hill is that members of parliament have a right to confidentiality but Ministers do not.
—Not when it is a formal consultation like this.

—Senator Hill's remark concerns me considerably. He says that, as long as there is a formality which is defined by half the Senate or more than half the Senate, whatever goes on should be made public. No doubt diaries were made by the people who were at the meeting. I think it is wrong for the Senate or for this Parliament to compel people who have gone to private meetings or public meetings to put forward their diaries or any notes that they made about a meeting that has taken place. That gets us to an absurd situation. All of us keep thoughts in our head. That is what the Opposition will be after next. It will want to know what our real thoughts are.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I follow that through and see where we get to? There is a public statement by Mrs Kelly as to what happened at the meeting; there is a public statement by the others as to what happened. The Opposition says, `That is not sufficient. We want to get this information so that we can cross-examine you, Mrs Kelly, and say that what you said publicly is not correct'. That is almost getting down to being thought police. The important thing as far as government is concerned is what Ministers say publicly. The Government's position is what is said publicly by Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to speak for 30 minutes?

—If Senator Macdonald keeps interrupting, certainly. It is clearly wrong in principle that the Senate or the House of Representatives should be able to go on a fishing expedition to find material that they may be able to use to embarrass the Government or any particular Minister when that Minister has acted correctly and properly. Let us get this clear: Mrs Kelly, in her public statements, has acted quite correctly, with complete integrity; there is nothing in her public utterances that could be condemned.
—But she is in the Keating camp.

—That remark from one of the most outstanding intellects on the Opposition bench, Senator Kemp, shows us what this is all about. Senator Kemp reveals the position of the other side. The Opposition wants to use this to embarrass the Government over the leadership struggle. Let us be clear that this censure motion is not an attempt to get to the truth of a matter that is of vital public interest; it is an attempt by the Opposition to fish in that tape to see whether it can find something that can be used to embarrass the Government over the leadership position. It has nothing to do with the environment or with any government portfolio. The comment from Senator Kemp clearly illustrates that this is an attempt to embarrass this Government over the leadership struggle by getting to somebody's private tapes.
—They are the ones with the leadership struggle.

—Of course. The Opposition says that the public interest is at stake. It has not been able to produce any evidence as to what public interest it has in mind. If there is material available-if it is a confidential taping of a public or private meeting-and it is in the public interest to reveal it, then it is proper for the Parliament to do something about it. But we simply cannot go fishing. By the very nature of the process, it is unfair on Ministers to simply go fishing among their confidential material in the hope of finding something to embarrass a government with. If the Opposition is proclaiming the public interest, it has to produce some evidence that on this tape there is something that goes to the issue of how the Government is governing.
—Give us a transcript of it and I will argue that case.

—Senator Kemp again illustrates exactly what I am saying. He says, `Give us a transcript and we will tell you what is in the public interest'. The Opposition has to point to something that suggests it is in the public interest and then ask for the tape; it cannot simply go fishing. If the Opposition does that, we might as well get everybody's diary, everybody's tape. That is the alarming thing about this. The Opposition cannot produce any evidence to show that this tape goes to the public interest. The best evidence I have to illustrate that is the words of that famous figure, Senator Kemp, one of the great intellects on the Opposition side of the chamber-perhaps one of the best minds over there--
—Careful!

—I am including Senator Short. Senator Kemp, on behalf of the Opposition, says, `Give us the tape and then we will tell you where the public interest is'. Senator Alston will be speaking to this motion after me. I want to hear him on this. Does he disagree with Senator Kemp's position that this is a fishing expedition to find some material to put against Mrs Kelly? If the Opposition had some evidence that Mrs Kelly in some way had not done her duty, that she had departed from her ministerial responsibility, we could look at things. But the Opposition cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators have quoted Odgers. The sixth edition of Odgers Australian Senate Practice states:
The sixth edition contends that the Executive Government enjoys no privilege which puts it above Parliament-
I agree-
having in mind that an overriding principle of the parliamentary system of government is, and must be, the accountability of the Executive to Parliament.
I agree.
Any recognition of Executive privilege, as an unchallengeable right, to deny information to Parliament, is inconsistent with that fundamental principle.
It says that Parliament can do this and Parliament can do that. What Odgers cannot do and what we cannot do is rise above the Constitution. The Constitution says:

The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is herein-after called ``The Parliament'' or ``The Parliament of the Commonwealth''.

It is not the Parliament that has called for this; it is the Senate. One cannot identify the Senate as the Parliament. Whether there are any rights or wrongs, or whether there is any public interest in this at all, if both Houses called on Mrs Kelly to reveal the tape then she would have to do it no matter what the rights or wrongs of it were. The fact of the matter is that the Parliament has not done it. No matter how august a chamber this is-and I have a great respect for it-one cannot elevate the Senate to the position of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What!
—One cannot do that. The Constitution, which we all obey, defines Parliament as the two Houses and the Queen.
—The standing orders do not say that. Standing Order 164 does not require both Houses to do it; it only requires the Senate to do it.

—Senator O'Chee is on a different argument. He should stick to the point that I am making about the Parliament. The Opposition cannot produce any evidence to impugn the reputation of Minister Kelly who, at this point in time, has the ability to stand tall as a Minister, as a person and as a member of parliament. By going on a fishing expedition the Opposition hopes that it will find something whereby it can embarrass Mrs Kelly and the Government. We should not tolerate that process.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter that has been pointed out to me is that-and everybody agreed that it was a private meeting, although my argument is that it does not matter whether it was or it was not-the only person who said that it was not a private meeting was Phil Gilding, who was not at the meeting.

From the speakers who follow me, honourable senators will hear whatever evidence there is to impugn Mrs Kelly. No doubt they will be able to lay some reasonable basis on which one can say that the public interest requires us to produce those documents-something above and beyond the proposition that, if we had a look, we would be able to find something. If one looked at anybody's private papers one would probably be able to find something about that person. But that is not how we should operate in this House because that leads to a complete injustice.

On that point, it is not in this country that the Parliament is supreme. The real proposition is that the rule of law is supreme. One of the great propositions in the rule of law under the Westminster system under which we operate in the Commonwealth is that persons are entitled to preserve their reputation of innocence and their integrity unless some evidence can be produced to show that they should be diminished in some way. Only when that evidence is produced can we look to furthering that material, not as the Opposition is doing here; that is, making the allegation that there is something on those tapes, and then going on a fishing expedition and hoping against hope-because that is what it would be-that it will find something on the tape.

What we ought to do-but will not because of the party politics in this matter-is reject this motion and leave Mrs Kelly as she is with her outstanding reputation as a Minister, a member of parliament and a person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been quite an extraordinary performance this morning, has it not? It was almost Alice in Wonderland. Honourable senators have heard two speakers from the Government side, Rumpole and Robespierre. If we look at what Rumpole had to say, it is quite clear that he got a dock brief that was handed back at the last minute. I trust that he will be marking it `fee declined'. In a sense it is quite unfortunate that he feels so bound by his instructions that he had to take riding orders that told him that numbers override principles. If there is one thing that Senator Cooney has been noted for in this place it is his commitment to very important parliamentary principles and the rule of law-which I think we all hold in high regard, and we hold him in high regard for advocating them.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why it is very unfortunate that he should resort to such sophistry as the proposition that somehow the overriding principle in this debate is a rule that says that persons' reputations are so sacred that we should not be entitled to inspect any documents relating to them. Whose reputation is on the line at the moment? What about the people who were called liars by Minister Kelly? Are they not entitled to a fair hearing?

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want the tape released.

—I will come to that in a moment. I suspect that Senator Richardson is the one who really takes the view-not Senator Cooney-that numbers matter before principles. At the end of the day, Senator Cooney knows what the responsibilities of the Executive are. He understands that either House of Parliament is entitled-as this one has done-to resolve that certain matters be put before it and that the obligation of the Executive is to account to that House of Parliament, not to treat it with contempt and not to say, `We will not comply.'

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go back to the 1982 episode. At that time Senator Chaney, on behalf of the Government in the Senate, put the proposition that those documents should not be released because it was not in the interests of the administration of justice and might well have prejudiced the private affairs of those whose taxation details might have been disclosed and that there was a good and proper reason in the public interest.

We have not heard one skerrick of a defence along those lines-not Executive privilege, not commercial-in-confidence and, if one looks at what Senator Richardson did the other day, not even a decent freedom of information defence. I would have thought that the moment the Government put in a request it would be insulted if it was told that there was a need for an internal review. The Government ought to look at the Minister, take his word at face value and hand over the tape. Hopefully, we will not have to wait too much longer before we get the true details of this sordid affair.

There is a public interest here. In many respects the interest lies in knowing whether the Greens have been defamed by the Minister and, indeed, in knowing what the real agenda is all about. In that regard, I think it is perfectly plain what the real agenda item ought to be. It is whether Mrs Kelly is speaking with a forked tongue; whether she is, on the one hand, publicly accepting her responsibility of Cabinet solidarity and, therefore, supporting new federalism or, on the other hand, privately bagging it and telling the Greens that this is all the fault of those sordid Premiers or, indeed, a Prime Minister who is forcing her into it. The issue is whether we have a Government and a Minister who are singing the same song. If the Government thinks that the public is not interested in knowing whether these matters are real or false it does not have much of a concept of the public interest.

Let us look at what our other friend, Senator Richardson, had to contribute earlier. I found it quite extraordinary that the world's greatest self-political fixer should somehow come into this chamber and purport to give us a lecture on parliamentary practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least I now understand crowded Casino; how big it was.
—Who did he quote? Mind you, this is the failed law student who has suddenly become an expert on constitutional law. Do honourable senators know who he quoted?
—You are a failed politician.

—I will not even bother with Senator Faulkner. Senator Richardson quoted Erskine and May. There is no such publication. All of us know that it is Erskine May-first name Erskine, last name May. But no, even a brief stint at law school before he was given the chop was not sufficient for him to understand how important that book on parliamentary practice is. That is about the best that we can get from the Government in terms of an analysis of the issues. It is perfectly clear that Senator Richardson's self-serving justification ought not to be taken at face value.

SPEECH.PARA: It is extraordinary to ask when this document was first claimed to be private. Is it really private to call together a meeting of all those groups around the country which have a vital interest in an issue and not say anything to them beforehand; not say, `Righto, chaps, off the record, without prejudice' and tell them not to say a word to their friends and relatives? Is it really a private meeting if we do not say any of that but just call them in, away they go, and at the end of the meeting-or maybe seven days later-say, `By the way, don't say a word to anyone'? That is how it works.

Suddenly we have this defence trotted out that this was all off the record. But was it? The Greens were all over the front page of the Weekend Australian telling us chapter and verse, backing it up with the minutes of the meeting, and demonstrating what they say was a very important contradiction between Minister Kelly's public position and her private stance. Then we have all this other self-serving nonsense about how this is private and somehow something that no-one should breathe a word about. If we took that at face value, what would be the logical consequence? No-one would release a word of it. What did we have yesterday? They came along with a self-serving selected extract from the very document they claim is private. In other words, because it suits their political advantage after they got such thrashing in the media over the last few days--

TALK.START.PARA: —And in the House.

—Everywhere. They decided then to selectively release a portion. What is privacy? Is privacy partial? Is privacy defined as releasing those parts that help me, irrespective of whether they damage someone else? Is privacy a question of deciding, `There are words here which might somehow get me off the hook politically, which might be able to turn the tide for a day or two, so we will breach our self-proclaimed notion of privacy and trot out a few garbled and equivocal words'?-I would have thought that, if anything, would dig Minister Kelly in even deeper. They make it perfectly clear that she is fundamentally opposed to new federalism. Whatever she chooses now to say about crass politics, she is bucketing those who adhere to it. If the Government wants to pretend she is bucketing the Premiers, let it do so, but who did the deal with the Premiers? The Prime Minister.
—You have one more to go and you have got the casino.
