—That point escapes me. What we have here is a criticism that goes to the very heart of the Government's commitment to new federalism. It cannot have one party to an agreement. If the Premiers are to be criticised by the Minister for espousing new federalism, for all those base reasons, such as being interested in selling their grandmothers for a quid and all these other disgraceful notions, what is to be said about the other party to the agreement? Why did he go along with it? Should he still adhere to it? The Government cannot have it both ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, Minister Kelly is publicly undermining the stance of the Prime Minister on this issue. She is probably taking her riding orders from those who were trotting out notes to her in the House the other day. What a demeaning spectacle: she is in the Cabinet; she is up there making a speech; and here we have Mr Keating passing her little bits of paper telling her how to run her argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the floor meetings of Chaney and Hewson after they got done over?

—One is entitled to have a bit of a chat, but I would have thought a Minister was able to defend herself. Really and truly-to have to rely on a piece of paper from a failed leadership pretender! Of course, Senator Richardson is going down with him, so I can understand his concern. Clearly, if that is the sort of position Minister Kelly gets herself into, it is quite understandable that she should be squirming in the way she has been.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite cannot pretend for a moment that this is not linked to the leadership. They will remember the way in which Senator Richardson managed to beat this whole thing up to the point where Mr Keating actually had a run. What was the great tactic? Go around the countryside denying that there is any such thing on the agenda, supposedly hosing it all down by telling people that there is not an issue, that all these rumours are nonsense, the whole time upping the ante, getting people more and more excited and creating an environment in which somebody can actually have a go. They had a go and they are still going-out the back door.

Clearly, what Mrs Kelly is on about is taking this sort of advice to new heights; that is, getting out there and allowing something to swing for some days to create all the fuss and bother. If the Government was fair dinkum, why would it not have released even that selected piece of the transcript on day one? Why choose to do it now? It has been done purely to try to deflect all the odium that is attaching to this indefensible position. I would have thought the very least we are entitled to in this chamber is a proper explanation of why the Government takes the line it does.

Even taking Senator Cooney's position at its highest, the very least Senator Button could have done was to say, `Dear Sir, you cannot have the document because it is not in the public interest'. I would have thought that was a pretty poor defence-Senator Cooney certainly would not charge for drafting it-but at least it would have offered some sort of explanation. We did not even get that. We got no justification at all-a studied contempt, a degree of arrogance I would have thought was quite breathtaking.

It is indicative of this Government's determination to tough it out, to provide what information it wants to the Parliament, or to either House, on its terms. If that is not the very antithesis of parliamentary democracy, if that is not flying in the face of those principles that failed law students and others think are important, it would seem that this Government does not even understand the basis on which it occupies the benches opposite.

If ever there were a clear-cut case of a government being in an indefensible position, of choosing on its own terms to be selective and ignore all the precedents and practice of this chamber, it is this one. The motion we are considering today, and which I commend the Democrats for supporting, simply makes it clear that there are rights, responsibilities and obligations on the Executive and individual Ministers to be accountable. At the very least, the Government should come into this chamber via Ministers of the crown and provide a decent explanation for the conduct it adopts. But we have had none of that. We have simply had a thumbing of their collective nose at this chamber and this Parliament. That is what we are condemning today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought it was sad to listen to this debate and to listen to the performance by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and his supporters as to why this particular document should not be produced today. It was very telling that in the letter to the Clerk of the Senate from Senator Button no reason was given for refusing to produce the tape. No reason was tendered by the Leader of the Government in this place for not producing the tape.

We listened carefully to the Minister, Senator Cooney and Senator Faulkner to learn what the reasons were. I suggest that this matter is of high constitutional interest and of high constitutional practice. It is not a trivial issue. The reason the Minister gave was that the House-the other place-had decided not to produce the tape. By some peculiar misquote from Erskine May this was deemed to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean Erskine and May!

—No. As Senator Alston pointed out, Erskine May. The misquote and highly selective quote failed to tackle the substantive point, that is, that this Senate has the right to determine its own rules and has the right to manage its own business. If we accepted the argument of the Minister there would be no reason for this chamber to exist because, once the other place had determined its view on a Bill or a particular matter of public importance, as far as the Government is concerned that would be sufficient and, therefore, would bind this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that in the history of federation any other Minister would have advanced such a stupid, silly argument. On 20 previous occasions, 20 previous governments have obeyed the order of the Senate and have produced documents. How can Government senators argue that the Senate does not have these particular powers? Were 20 other governments quite wrong?

The extraordinary thing about this debate is that this document and the tapes and the transcripts that are now available to certain selected people are not apparently available to the Prime Minister or to the Ministers who are standing up in the other place and in this chamber and defending Ros Kelly. Those people have been very careful to avoid making any claim that they have actually heard the tapes or read the transcript. They are prepared to come in here and into the other place and defend Mrs Kelly without having taken the trouble to actually read what those transcripts contain. That is somewhat extraordinary, I would have thought.

We are therefore entitled to speculate about what is on those tapes. We have before us three sentences from a transcript of a meeting that went on for three hours. So we are quite entitled to speculate about what precisely is on these tapes. What is the Government afraid of? What particular item of information is contained on these tapes? Are the Government and Mrs Kelly worried, for example, about the robust language she reportedly used during the three-hour meeting? It was very robust indeed.

We have a slight hint of the sort of language Mrs Kelly uses when we read those three sentences, I suggest, where she accused many of her Labor colleagues-Labor Premiers-of being willing to sell their mothers for the big dollar. That is the sort of language we have a hint of and which we have reports that Mrs Kelly apparently used during this three-hour meeting. Maybe this tape reveals the nature of the grubby deals this Government had done with various Green groups prior to the last election. Maybe there was a fairly vigorous exchange on that issue. Maybe there were some comments about the money the Government had paid out to some of those groups and the trade-offs that were required. Maybe there was a fairly vigorous exchange on that issue.

How interesting it would be for the public, I say to Senator Cooney, who spoke about public interest, to explore those issues. We know that the man in charge of that was none other than the Minister at the table, Senator Richardson. So we are entitled to think and speculate about what is on that tape.

I was intrigued by Senator Faulkner's comments about the nature of the debate yesterday in the other place and what the final results of it were. He urged us to look at the press. I looked at the press, and here in the Australian we see the headline, `Kelly, Keating out on a limb'. In view of Senator Faulkner's interest in this matter, in view of his strong support for Mr Hawke, one thing he would not be worried about is Kelly and Keating being out on a limb. I suggest to Senator Faulkner that perhaps in the fullness of time we can speculate that the Prime Minister, if he takes the trouble to read the full text of that transcript--

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not game to.

—I am not too sure that he is not. I think the matter will become quite clear, with the factional plays in the Labor Party. Unlike Senator Faulkner, I will not comment on anything that may be private or not private. So I suggest to Senator Faulkner that it is possible that, in the fullness of time, as this issue heats up-and let me say that it is going to heat up; it is not over by any stretch of the imagination-Mr Hawke may be prepared to insist that the documents be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: On the front page of the Canberra Times, which we all read in the morning, it is reported that Mr Hawke said, referring to Mrs Kelly:
I would not be unhappy if she tabled the relevant transcript. I agree entirely with it.

There is a little chink; there is the door being pushed slightly ajar. I suggest to Mr Hawke that the public will at least want to know why he has not bothered to read the transcript, why the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has not bothered to read the transcript. I remind my colleagues that Senator Button was asked twice by Senator Reid yesterday during Question Time whether he had bothered to read the transcript. Senator Button was very careful to make it clear that no Minister had yet bothered to read the full transcript. So I say to Senator Cooney: where does that leave the public interest? Who can judge? The Government's own people are too scared to read this transcript-and I will bet they have jolly good reason to be. This is a vital issue of constitutional practice. The Senate is entitled to pursue this matter with great vigour, and the Senate will do so.

Senator Faulkner raised some issues concerning what happened in 1982, and he boldly waved around a bit of paper. As he has drawn that debate to our attention, I refer him to some interesting quotes by his colleague Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I will read into the transcript of this debate what the now Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade said on that occasion:
It is only by access to these documents that it will be possible now, given the attitude that the Government has taken, for an objective view to be reached as to where the merits and the truth lie.

Does that ring a somewhat familiar bell? If the Government has anything to hide, then this is what its shadow Attorney-General said in 1982. So I can understand the Government's continued reluctance to make the documents available. He said:

If the Government believes, however, that its Minister and senior officials have acted throughout reasonably and with a proper sense of responsibility to the public at large, the Government should not hesitate for one second to put these documents in the public domain to enable the truth of that perception to be established once and for all.
That is not a bad quote from Senator Evans in 1982. I thank Senator Faulkner for drawing our attention to it. Senator Evans concluded:
If there is any constitutional issue involved here it is the right of this Parliament to demand accountability from the Executive . . .

I would have thought that was a fairly devastating comment from another man who holds himself out to be an eminent legal expert, although not as eminent, I regret to say, as I have often thought Senator Cooney to be. Having served with him on a number of committees, I felt that he was a man of great principle and a man of great learning. I have to say that the contribution he made today will not stand up well when the history of this period is written. I am sorry about that, because the contributions he often makes are of great worth and great merit.
I strongly support the motion before the chair. Whether this motion is won or lost, I point out to Senator Cooney, will not end the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seriousness of the censure motion before the Senate cannot be emphasised too much. We know that, when one similar request occurred in 1975 and the Whitlam Government refused, it went to the people and was defeated.

I have noted the text of the order and advise the Senate that the Government will not be tabling the tape recording to which it refers.

Yesterday in the House of Representatives the motion of censure against the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories was lost because of the numbers-nothing else. The Government said, `We are not going to give you those documents. We will not do it. You can request them, but it comes down to numbers and numbers only'. Because it has the numbers in the House of Representatives, it does not intend to comply with the direction of the Senate.

There was nothing in Senator Cooney's contribution about Executive accountability to the Parliament. He said, `We on this side do what we are told; nothing more, nothing less. I am still here and my colleagues who crossed the floor are still here but, unfortunately, the only member of the Labor Party who had the courage to cross the floor on any issue-Senator Georges-was expelled from the Labor Party as a result of his crossing the floor. That is the sort of democracy we know, and we have learnt, that the Labor Party indulges in: `Vote for a principle against your numbers and you will be expelled'.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The 308th Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) was tabled in both Houses on 14 March 1991.

The report presents the findings of the committee's inquiry into the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) `Unofficial Account'. The report includes a number of recommendations, most of which are systemic in nature, aimed at improving Commonwealth management and administration.

A number of the recommendations made by the JCPA have direct relevance to the Parliamentary Departments while others have wider implications. We have therefore responded to all nine of the Committee's recommendations in the report as set out below.

We are confident that implementation of the Committee's recommendations will ensure effective safeguards are in place to protect the interests of the Parliamentary Departments, will result in improved financial disciplines and strengthen accountability mechanisms.
Recommendation 1:

The Department of Administrative Services review the guidelines and procedures regarding the disposal of surplus, unserviceable or obsolete assets to ensure that the arrangements currently in place are adequate, clearly understood and properly implemented. (paragraph 2.5)
Response:
Whilst this recommendation does not directly involve the Parliamentary Departments, they are assessing the adequacy of the guidelines and procedures and ensuring adherence to them.
Recommendation 2:

As part of the induction process, all new entrants to the Australian Public Service be briefed on the financial legal framework affecting public servants' dealings with Commonwealth financial resources. (paragraph 2.55)
Response:

Although this recommendation has implications for the wider Public service, all Parliamentary Departments have taken action to implement this recommendation. Formal induction processes have been, or are being, developed by all Parliamentary Departments. Briefing on the financial legal framework is recognised as a major part of that process.

In future, all Parliamentary Departments will include, in literature made available to all new employees, an outline of the legal framework for public servants who are involved in the administration of Commonwealth financial resources.

Departmental officers who have ongoing responsibility for financial administration will continue to use formal financial documentation made available to them and will be reminded regularly of their responsibilities to be aware of, and comply with, the relevant laws and regulations.
All Parliamentary Departments have issued, or are in the process of issuing, Secretary's Instructions to ensure that departmental staff are clearly informed as to their responsibilities.
Recommendation 3:
The Commonwealth Government examine ways to ensure its major contractors comply with relevant Commonwealth legislation and operating policies which impinge on contracts. (paragraph 2.55)
Response:

Although this recommendation requires action by the Government, the Joint House Department has advised that the following actions and procedures are currently in place or in the process of implementation within that department:
standard contract documents which more clearly define the contractual and legislative obligations of the contractor are being developed;

a Purchasing and Supply Manual outlining both policy and procedures for departmental staff involved with procurement action for their sections has been endorsed by the Secretary, Joint House Department, and is currently being printed prior to distribution;

training seminars are being conducted for departmental officers designed to reinforce understanding of their obligations with respect to Commonwealth policy when dealing with contractors or when placed in a contract administration capacity;
procedures are being developed in consultation with client areas to more closely monitor contractor performance against terms and conditions of the contract, and

it is a requirement that all contract change/amendment/cancellation actions be firstly cleared and subsequently formalised by the Purchasing and Services Section in the form of a formal contract amendment.
Similar action has been, or is being, taken by the other Parliamentary Departments where appropriate.
Comment on Recommendations 3 and 4:

These two recommendations in no way relieve senior public servants or contractors to the Commonwealth of their responsibility to be aware of, and comply with, the relevant laws and regulations. (paragraph 3.41)
Response:
Parliamentary executive officers are aware of their responsibilities and the requirement to comply with all relevant laws and regulations. Specific action has been taken to ensure this.
Recommendation 4:
All Commonwealth Departments ensure that cancellation of purchase order requests be clearly documented to show on whose authorisation the cancellation was made and for what reason. (paragraph 3.41)
Response:
All Parliamentary Departments have implemented procedures to give effect to the committee's recommendation.
Recommendation 5:
The Parliamentary Librarian take appropriate action to recover from Mr Blume his outstanding debt of $330 to the Commonwealth. (paragraph 4.41)
Response:
Following a letter sent to Mr Blume on 12 April 1991 by the Parliamentary Librarian asking for settlement of the debt, Mr Blume paid the outstanding sum of $330.
Recommendation 6:
Each Parliamentary Department that has not already done so should establish, as a matter of priority, an adequately resourced internal audit function. (paragraph 6.19)
Response:

All Parliamentary Departments have entered into contractual arrangements for the supply of internal audit services with the accounting firm Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu. The Parliamentary Departments are fully committed to ongoing internal audit activity, although the method of achieving this through an internal audit consultancy or an in-house function will be reviewed from time to time.
All departments either have in place an approved internal audit charter and an audit program, or are taking action in this regard as a matter of urgency.
Recommendation 7:

The delegate of the Secretary of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff review the actions of the former Manager of PISO, Mr Goodall and PISO's former Director, Planning and Administration, Mr Blume, with regard to establishing whether any misconduct may have occurred or whether there was a failure to fulfil their duties as officers while employed in the Australian Public Service. Should this be the case, an appropriate record be placed on the relevant personal files to ensure that this is taken into account in the event that either individual seeks reappointment to the Service. (paragraph 8.34)
Response:

Following the receipt of Report 308, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff wrote to the Public Service Commission on 2 April 1991 requesting that the Commission nominate a suitably qualified officer to act as the Secretary's delegate to review the issues and advise the Secretary on the above matters.

It was considered that seeking an officer from outside the Department to carry out the review was the most appropriate method of ensuring that the principles of natural justice were followed and that no allegations of bias could be made. In a letter dated 19 June 1991 the Commissioner advised that the Public Service Commission was unable to assist.

Following receipt of this advice the Department engaged the services of Mr Brian Smith a retired former Senior Executive Service officer of the Australian Public Service to conduct the review and prepare a report and any appropriate associated recommendations. Mr Smith has now completed his review and on his recommendation notations have been placed on the personal files of both Messrs Blume and Goodall.
Recommendation 8:

Finance regulation 133 be revised to ensure that penalties for breaching the Finance Regulations can be applied not only to current accounting officers or persons subject to the Audit Act 1901, but also to persons breaching the Regulations who are no longer accounting officers or persons subject to the Audit Act 1901. (paragraph 8.34)
Response:
This recommendation is a matter for consideration by the Department of Finance.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, I present the report of the Committee on the retiring age of judges of the Family Court of Australia, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The Committee has resolved to address item (h) of its Terms of Reference, the retiring age of judges of the Family Court of Australia, in this first report.

The only federal court to have a maximum retiring age of less than 70 years is the Family Court of Australia. Section 23A, which established 65 as the maximum retiring age, was inserted into the Family Law Act in 1977 following the amendment to section 72 of the Constitution. Prior to this judges of the Family Court of Australia were appointed for life.

It was felt at that time that the provision of the 65 retiring age was a reflection of community concern. Due to the demanding and arduous nature of some of the disputes it was considered that there was good reason for requiring judges of the Family Court to retire by the age recognised as the maximum retiring age for most other occupations in the community.
The major arguments advanced both for and against retaining the present retirement age of 65 years for Family court Judges have been examined.
The Committee does not believe, in the light of the evidence available to it, that there would be any valid reason to consider lowering the maximum retiring age to less than 65 years.

It is acknowledged that Family Law matters may cause a significant level of stress as a result of the often highly emotional issues involved, for example, in access and custody disputes and the distribution of the assets of a marriage, however the Committee believes that the issues dealt with in some of the other federal courts, where the retiring age is 70 years, would be equally stressful.

A number of judges hold dual commissions with the Federal Court and the Family Court. The Committee believes that it is an unusual situation to have a retiring age of 65 years for Family Court Judges and 70 years for Federal Court Judges where a dual commission is held.

The importance of awareness of social values for Family Court Judges was also considered by the Committee. The Committee believes that there would not be a substantial difference, between the social values of judges who are 65 years and those who are 70 years of age.

In coming to decisions in relation to matters before him or her the judge would hear from solicitors, witnesses, counsellors and registrars. The judge's experience is then brought to bear in bringing all these threads together and reaching a conclusion.

The issue of judicial burnout was raised as a concern by one Family Court Judge. It was suggested that if the retiring age were to be extended it should be subject to the provision that no judge should continue beyond 65 if he or she had more than 20 years service at that time. A judge who is suffering from stress or burnout has the option of retiring at age 60 but must have ten years service to qualify for a judicial pension. The Committee believes that the issue of judicial burnout may warrant further consideration.

The Committee believes that there is no reason to assume that judges of the Family Court have a diminished capacity to make sound decisions after age 65 when all other federal court judges are considered competent to adjudicate up to age 70.

Since the early days of the Family Court the processes of the Court have been refined. Routine and uncontested matters are now determined by registrars and judicial registrars leaving the judges to preside and adjudicate in the more complex contested cases that come before the court.

Despite this refinement to the operation of the court the Committee has received many complaints relating to the length of time taken for particular cases to be heard. It has been suggested to the Committee that there is a need for more Family Court Judges. By forcing judges to retire at age 65 the problem will simply increase. The Committee believes that valuable expertise is being lost to the Family Court through the early retirement of Family Court Judges.

In its early years the Family Court had a specialised jurisdiction, but this role has been considerably expanded to include not only property cases and issues relating to children but also matters previously dealt with by the Federal Court of Australia.

Disputes about property in the Family Court can raise complex questions relating to such areas of the law as property, equity, taxation, contract, company, constitutional and conflict law. Similar questions may be raised in other superior courts where the retiring age is 70 years.

It would appear to the Committee that if a judge of a Supreme Court, up to the age of 70, is able to preside over a matter relating to children, there is no logical reason that a Family Court Judge would be any less able to do so beyond the age of 65 years. The same can be said of the appeal process in the Family Court. An appeal from the Family Court is first heard by the Full Court of the Family Court. Any subsequent appeal is heard by the High Court whose judges have a maximum retiring age of 70 years.

The jurisdiction of the Family Court has been increased. This increased jurisdiction can be seen in the provisions relating to cross-vesting. This legislation, introduced in 1977, has meant that the Family Court can exercise the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the State Supreme Courts in a number of matters. The legislation allows disputes involving a third party to be determined by the Family Court. In exercising this jurisdiction the Family Court is exercising jurisdiction that would otherwise come under State Supreme Courts.

The Family Court has often been treated as a poor relation compared to the Federal Court of Australia. It has generally lacked resources and the conditions of service for judges have been thought to be unequal to the other federal courts. There have been difficulties in the past in attracting the most suitable candidates to the Family Court. The Committee believes that an increase in the maximum retiring age for Family Court Judges would make the Family court a more attractive option for many experienced legal practitioners. By extending the retiring age the opportunity would be created for new judicial appointments to obtain the necessary experience under the guidance of senior Family Court Judges who may wish to continue past 65 years. With ten of the current judges of the Family Court, who have tenure until 65, due to retire in the next five years an extension of the maximum retiring age to 70 would allow greater time to attract the most appropriate people to the bench.

The reasons for fixing a 65 retiring age for the Family Court are no longer valid. The original basis for the decision on retiring age for Family Court Judges, due to the narrow jurisdiction of Family Law, has been considerably eroded. The role of the Family Court Judge is no longer one that deals exclusively with Family Law but may now involve similar matters to those heard in the Federal Court of Australia.

A recognition of the equal status of the Family Court to other superior courts would be further enhanced by increasing the maximum retiring age for Family Court Judges to age 70. By allowing Family Court Judges who are willing and able to remain at the bench, there could be a considerable cost saving to the Government and the community. Not only is the knowledge and ability of an experienced judge invaluable to newer appointees but it would represent a considerable saving in terms of costs associated with new judicial appointments.
Accordingly the Committee recommends that:
as a matter of priority the Family Law Act be amended to fix a maximum retiring age of 70 years for Family Court Judges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on a visit by the Defence Subcommittee to north Queensland and Torres Strait.

The statement read as follows-

Last month the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inspected defence facilities in north Queensland and the Torres Strait. The trip is significant because it is the first time that the Defence Sub-Committee has visited Torres Strait since the Sub-Committee came into existence in 1973.

Since 1973 familiarisation visits and inspections have been considered an essential part of the Sub-committee's activities. They provide the Members with opportunities to gain first hand appreciation of the capability of our Defence Force.

The Defence Sub-Committee has conducted rigorous inquiries into several Defence issues, for example, into the Management of Australia's Defence, into Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force-and now into the Australian Defence Force Reserve. The extent to which information gained during inspections complements the formal evidence submitted to inquiries cannot be overestimated.

On this occasion we visited an Army Reserve formation-11 Brigade at Townsville-where we were able to discuss issues which had been raised by the inquiry into Reserves in terms of 11 Brigade's experience.

In line with the wider educational value of familiarisation visits, the Sub-Committee inspected elements of the Australian Defence Force's Operational Deployment Force, namely 3 Brigade, and 5 Aviation Regiment and Operational Support Group at RAAF Townsville.

Whilst in Townsville the Sub-Committee was provided with an opportunity to participate as observers in a live-firing exercise. Members were carried with combat soldiers of 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment by Black Hawk assault helicopters to High Range Training Area where a platoon attack was made on a section post. We were impressed by the high level of skills demonstrated by the soldiers engaged in the exercise.

In Cairns the Sub-Committee was briefed at Headquarters 51st Battalion Far North Queensland Regiment which is a battalion of 11 Brigade. The 51st Battalion is also one of the Australian Army's three Regional Force Surveillance Units which has elements located throughout north Queensland.

The surveillance function of the 51st Battalion is complemented by the Patrol Boat Fleet based at Cairns and by Coastwatch. The itinerary therefore included briefings by both HMAS Cairns and the Australian Customs Service. Coastwatch enjoys a cooperative relationship with 51 FNQR through joint patrols and exchange of information.

In the Torres Strait region the Sub-Committee inspected the Depot at Thursday Island which C Company of the 51st Battalion shares with the Resident Naval Officer Thursday Island. We were briefed on the particular concerns of Reservists in the island communities.

We gained some perspectives on the value of a Defence presence on the islands of the Torres Strait from discussions with the Chairman of the Island Co-ordinating Council, Mr Getano Lui and with the Chairmen of Boigu and Saibai Islands, Mr Donald Banu and Mr Terry Waia, respectively.

Boigu and Saibai Islands are located within three or four kilometres of the Papua-New Guinea coast. We were told that some time ago rumours had circulated that `Raskols' had left Port Moresby with the intention of causing strife on the islands. The Chairmen of both islands made it clear to the Sub-Committee that they would like a more visible Defence presence. They would appreciate more visits by Defence authorities and more consultation on recruitment of Reserves.
The Sub-Committee also visited Yorke Island because an exercise was being held there for Reservists. This gave us an opportunity to speak to Reservists about their activities in the Army Reserve.

At Weipa we were briefed on the operations of the Reserve patrols in the area of operations of B Company. The Officer Commanding B Company confirmed the view put to the Sub-Committee on other occasions that the most valued training exercises are those involving `real' tasks. For example, B Company patrols were required to assist in the search for the F/A-18 which disappeared.
The Sub-Committee also visited the COMALCO bauxite mine at Weipa where we gained an appreciation of protecting a vital asset in the northern region.
Members gained a great deal from this trip, from the experiences and the briefings provided throughout the tour.
The Sub-Committee is grateful to the Minister for Defence for making available the Caribou aircraft which transported us for most of the visit.
I commend the report to the House.

Introduction

The 311th Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is a report on the Committee's activities for the financial year 1990-91 and informs the Parliament of the work undertaken by a committee concerned with issues of accountability, the financial affairs of the Commonwealth and the achievement of value for money for the taxpayer's dollar.
The year has been an extremely busy one for the Committee. It conducted 7 inquiries, tabled 5 reports, and together with its four Sectional Committees met 111 times for a total of 285 hours.
Reports
The Committee's reports have dealt with several diverse issues which include:
an investigation of the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (or PISO) `unofficial account';
a review of annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities; and
an examination of Australia's Business Migration Program.

Each of these reports has been a catalyst for change and I note in particular, the Report on the Business Migration Program. Only one month after tabling, the Minister for Immigration announced the Government's acceptance of the Committee's recommendations-effectively dismantling the Business Migration Program.
It is fair to say few reports of parliamentary committees receive such prompt attention and lead to such dramatic change.
Annual Report Guidelines

The Committee's activities are not limited to the conduct of inquiries. The Public Services Act requires the Committee to approve the guidelines for the preparation of departmental annual reports and this year the Committee reviewed a revised set of guidelines prepared by the Prime Minister's Department.

The Committee approved the annual report guidelines subject to the Prime Minister agreeing to certain changes to them. One important change was that House of Representatives Standing Committees be assigned the ongoing role of reviewing the operations of Commonwealth departments based on the departmental annual reports tabled in the Parliament.

I am happy to report that this task has now formally been given to the House Standing Committees.I believe the work of the House Standing Committees in this regard will complement the work undertaken by their Senate counterparts-and, I am hopeful that the combined efforts of the House and Senate Standing Committees will contribute to the enhanced accountability of the Executive Government to the Parliament.
Inquiries

research and development in Australia;

the Australian Customs Service; and
the role and work of the Independent Auditor-that is, the auditor who audits the Auditor-General.
I believe the diversity of these inquiries indicates the Committee's clear interest in all areas of Commonwealth administration.
Conclusion
The achievements of the Public Accounts Committee reflect the commitment and hard work of its members, staff and advisers and I take this opportunity to express my thanks to them.
On behalf of the Committee, I would also place on record our appreciation for the assistance provided by the Auditor-General and his staff and the Department of Finance.

Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill

In May 1989 the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters presented its Report No. 3, which flowed from its Inquiry into the Conduct of the 1987 Federal Election and the 1988 Referendums. A number of the recommendations made by the Committee in its Report have already been put into effect administratively or by regulation, and some others were enacted in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Act 1989.

This Bill amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 to give effect to the remaining recommendations made in the Committee's Report No. 3 which have been accepted by the Government. A number of minor amendments the need for which has become apparent since the Committee reported have also been included in the Bill.
Mr President, I turn to the major provisions of the Bill:

The Bill proposes that registered officers of political parties are to be able to nominate all endorsed House of Representatives candidates to the Australian Electoral Officer for the State or Territory concerned up to 48 hours before the close of nominations. It is also proposed that nominations may be made by facsimile provided the deposit is also received before the close of nominations.

The Bill also imposes a new requirement on a candidate to state in his or her nomination whether he or she became an Australian citizen by birth, by naturalisation or by other means. This should minimise the possibility of the election results being subsequently voided by the courts because the candidate is not an Australian citizen as occurred in the case of former Senator Wood.
The Bill also proposes that any person who at the hour of nomination is an officer of the Crown is not capable of being nominated as a Senator or a Member of the House of Representatives.
Any person who makes a claim on the nomination form which is false or misleading in a material respect shall be guilty of an offence, with a penalty of $3,000 or imprisonment for 6 months or both.

The Bill also proposes to introduce an infringement notice system for enforcement of compulsory voting at elections and referendums, under which apparent non-voters will be given the option of paying a penalty, showing cause why they should not be prosecuted, or having the matter dealt with by the court.
Mr President, other features of the Bill include:
provision for candidates who have silent enrolment not to have their addresses publicly announced;
ensuring that the addresses of silent electors will not be disclosed to persons inspecting postal vote applications;
giving Senators and Members the choice of recording their enrolled address or place of residence when completing their nomination forms;
enabling an incumbent Senator who has lodged a voting ticket to be included above the heavy black line on the Senate ballot paper along with the word `Independent';
clarifying the provisions relating to the scrutiny of Senate voting; and
modifying the provisions of section 351 relating to the publication of matter regarding candidates to enhance its enforceability.

The Bill also allows for the provision to each House of Representatives candidate a copy of the certified list of voters for the Division for which they have nominated as soon as possible after the close of the roll. It also allows for copies of the certified list of voters to be provided to Senators and Members as soon as practicable after the election.

I thank the Joint Standing Committee for their valuable contribution in reviewing the operation of the Electoral and Referendum Acts. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill
The Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1991 will provide a new representative action procedure in the Federal Court.
The new procedure will enhance access to justice, reduce the costs of proceedings and promote efficiency in the use of court resources.

Under the Bill a person will be able to bring a proceeding on behalf of a group of persons where the claims of those persons arise out of the same, similar or related circumstances and a common question of law or fact arises with respect to all their claims.
The new representative proceeding provided in the Bill is based on the existing representative action procedure in the Federal Court and in State Supreme Courts.

The Bill gives the Federal Court an efficient and effective procedure to deal with multiple claims. Such a procedure is needed for two purposes. The first is to provide a real remedy where, although many people are affected and the total amount at issue is significant, each person's loss is small and not economically viable to recover in individual actions.
It will thus give access to the courts to those in the community who have been effectively denied justice because of the high cost of taking action.

The second purpose is to deal efficiently with the situation where the damages sought by each claimant are large enough to justify individual actions and a large number of persons wish to sue the respondent.

The new procedure will mean that groups of persons, whether they be shareholders or investors, or people pursuing consumer claims, will be able to obtain redress and do so more cheaply and efficiently than would be the case with individual actions.

The procedure contained in the Bill has been developed following the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled `Grouped Proceedings in the Federal Court', which was tabled in Parliament in December 1988.

The Government was not able to accept all the Law Reform Commission's recommendations. In particular, it has not adopted the Commission's `grouped proceedings' approach or the extension of the Federal Court's jurisdiction for such proceedings. The Commission's proposals for contingency fees and a Grouped Proceedings Assistance Fund have also not been adopted.
The Government has engaged in an extensive consultative process in preparing this Bill and has received comment from the business community and consumer and legal groups.
Since I announced details of the Government's proposed reforms two matters of concern have been raised by some sections of the business community and of the consumer movement.

The area of concern to business appears to be whether persons having relevant claims against the respondent should be included in the group covered by the proceedings unless they choose to `opt out' or whether all such persons should have to take a positive step to be included, that is to `opt in'.

The Government believes that an opt out procedure is preferable on grounds both of equity and efficiency. It ensures that people, particularly those who are poor or less educated, can obtain redress where they may be unable to take the positive step of having themselves included in the proceedings. It also achieves the goals of obtaining a common binding decision while leaving a person, who wishes to do so, free to leave the group and pursue his or her claim separately.
Some consumer groups have expressed concern that the new procedure will not be available for causes of action arising before the commencement of the amending Act.

Practical considerations have led to the Bill applying only to future causes of action. These are the possible insurance implications of enabling increased recovery of claims in respect of past premium years and the possible impact on the Federal Court if past claims could be brought.

The only likely costs to business of the reforms in the Bill will be through people being able to enforce existing substantive rights which claimants could not previously afford to enforce even though the liabilities existed.
This is to the benefit of ethical businesses which honour their legal obligations without having to be forced to do so by legal action.

The other main feature of the Bill is the comprehensive powers given to the Court to ensure that the proceedings are not abused. The Court will be able to order that a proceeding no longer continue as a representative proceeding where it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so because, amongst other matters, it would be less expensive to have separate proceedings or that the relief sought could be obtained by means of an individual proceeding. It will retain all its current powers including the power to stay or dismiss any application it considers to be vexatious, oppressive or trivial. The Court is also given power to stay or discontinue any representative action where it considers that the costs of identifying group members and distributing money ordered to be paid to them would be excessive having regard to the total of the amount at issue.
These reforms are a significant part of the Government's equity and access policies embodied in its social justice program.

There is considerable community concern about the cost of, and access to, justice which is now the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The measures contained in this Bill will remove at least some of the barriers for persons who seek redress before the Courts.
The Bill represents a considered, balanced and responsible response to problems in an area where there is a recognised and pressing need for reform.
Following introduction of the Bill a period of time will be given to enable interested persons and groups to provide comments to the Government on its provisions.

It is not expected that the Bill will have a significant financial impact. A small number of additional cases may be brought. Offsetting this will be savings where multiple individual actions would otherwise be brought.
I present the explanatory memorandum for this Bill.

AUSSAT REPEAL BILL 1991

The Government's November 1990 statement on micro-economic reform outlined changes to take place in the provision of telecommunications services in Australia. As part of these reforms, AUSSAT Pty Ltd will be sold to form the basis of the Second Carrier. A number of regulatory changes have recently been made by the Parliament to create a competitive environment for the Second Telecommunications Carrier and new owner of AUSSAT.

The Commonwealth's 100% shareholding in AUSSAT is to be sold and general telecommunications and public mobile licences awarded. Once ownership of the shares is transferred, AUSSAT will cease to be a Government Business Enterprise. Accordingly, the AUSSAT Act 1984 will need to be repealed and a number of consequential provisions will need to be put in place so that the sale can be completed.
After the sale, AUSSAT will be a privately owned company and subject to the laws that presently govern the corporate operations of such companies in Australia.

Consequential provisions are also required to extinguish AUSSAT's tax losses, to empower the Treasurer to give an explicit Commonwealth guarantee to AUSSAT's borrowings up to the point of sale, to appropriate funds to pay out those borrowings prior to the sale and to remove AUSSAT from future coverage of other Commonwealth legislation such as the Archives Act.

Under s80 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a company may offset prior year losses against future income to reduce taxable income and income tax liability until such time as the accumulated losses have been used up.

AUSSAT's accumulated and projected trading losses to 30 June 1991 provide a potential future income tax benefit to a purchaser. While it is normal practice to sell an entity with any tax losses, doing so in this case would clearly have budgetary implications in future years. From a budgetary viewpoint, therefore, it is desirable that they be removed.

On the matter of AUSSAT's borrowings, in the period leading up to the sale, AUSSAT will continue to fund its operations from both revenues and borrowings. It is essential therefore that the viability of the borrowing program is maintained until it is paid out by the Commonwealth.
Because of AUSSAT's high gearing, investor support of its borrowing program in the lead up to the sale is heavily reliant on Commonwealth expressions of support for AUSSAT.
Paying out the debt prior to the sale will have a two fold effect. Firstly it will reassure lenders in the period prior to the payout and secondly it will facilitate the orderly sale of the company.

The appropriation provided for in the Bill is set at an estimated maximum amount allowing for contingencies such as the impact of variable interest rates applying to AUSSAT's borrowings between now and when they are paid out, the possible payout of one or both of AUSSAT's leveraged satellite leases as well as its commercial paper borrowings and any slippages in the timing of the payout due to factors relating to the sale itself. The figure is $800m, but the Bill provides for the actual appropriation to be set at an outturn figure below the maximum.
The need to pay out the leveraged leases will not be known until the bidders, the banks and the Commonwealth decide as part of the sale negotiations how the satellite leases are to be treated.
The amount of the debt payout will ultimately affect the price received for AUSSAT.

The explicit guarantee is required to support the restructuring of AUSSAT's borrowings in preparation for payout. Just prior to payout AUSSAT will consolidate its borrowings into a single credit instrument with the Commonwealth Bank to facilitate the logistics of payout.

For its part, because of its very large exposure to AUSSAT through this arrangement, the Commonwealth Bank has quite reasonably requested that the Commonwealth guarantee the credit instrument up to the point of sale.
The Bill provides for the guarantee to cease at the point of sale.

The Bill also makes minor amendments to other Commonwealth legislation consequential upon the repeal of the AUSSAT Act 1984 and, in respect of other telecommunications legislation in particular, to correct drafting anomalies and to clarify the technical operation of some of the provisions of that legislation.
Financial Impact

As indicated above, this Bill provides for a maximum of $800m which can be paid to AUSSAT in the form of additional share or loan capital. The amount actually paid will be determined by movements in interest rates between now and the time of payout, the timing of the actual payout and the treatment of the satellite leveraged leases. It is not possible nor desirable to predict what the incoming sale proceeds will be as this will be determined in the sale negotiation process.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.

ABORIGINAL EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE)
AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 amends the principal Act, the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989.

The principal Act provides a legislative basis for a consolidated program and funding approach that is supplementary to mainstream Commonwealth education funding. The Act underpins the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy. This policy, commonly known as the AEP, has been endorsed by Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. It is truly a national policy.

The AEP is a significant reform initiative in Aboriginal education developed when my colleague the honourable J S Dawkins was the Minister responsible for Aboriginal education.The AEP is a cooperative effort to address the education needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, by focusing on the educational strategies of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories, non-government education authorities and educational institutions, in achieving agreed national goals.
The AEP has a number of program elements including:
the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP), which incorporates the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness Program (ASSPA);
the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme (ATAS); and
Vocational and Educational Guidance for Aboriginals Scheme (VEGAS).
The AEP arose from the findings of several major reports that identified Aboriginal people as the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. It has four main long term objectives:
to increase the involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in educational decision making;
to ensure equality of access to educational services;
to ensure equity of educational participation; and
to achieve equitable and appropriate educational outcomes.
All governments of Australia have agreed on 21 specific goals which cover all sectors of education.

It should be noted that these amendments to the principal Act are administrative in nature. They will not affect the national policy nor the long-term commitment of the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, the non-government educational authorities and the educational institutions to achieve the goals.

The administrative amendments reflect the transfer of the higher education funding component within the principal Act to the Higher Education Funding Act and minor changes to the administration of the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program, the program which gives effect to the principal Act.

The Bill will not appropriate any additional funds. The amendments to the amounts appropriated under the principal Act also reflect budget neutral transfers between the special appropriation and the annual appropriation Bills.
The central features of the AEP will remain the same.

Firstly, as in other areas of Aboriginal affairs such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, or ATSIC, the policy emphasises the necessity for Aboriginal involvement in decision-making.

As an example at the school level, there are now over two thousand ASSPA committees. These are committees made up of Aboriginal parents and teachers, that meet and discuss program priorities in schools. The ASSPA program is recognised by State and Territory education authorities as being a successful means of increasing Aboriginal involvement in educational decision making at the local level. Such involvement occurs at all levels of the AEP.Secondly, the policy emphasises a cooperative approach at every level and operates with cross-party support. It links the work of education providers and State and Territory governments of all kinds through an agreed national approach.
The AEP is strategic. It is based on agreed operational and strategic plans intended to improve the poor national report card in Aboriginal education.

The AEP is working. We already have early indications that Aboriginal school retention rates, increasing steadily throughout the duration of the Hawke Government, have increased further. More Aboriginal people are becoming employed in education and more schooling opportunities are becoming available.

The AEP also has a relationship with two other areas of my responsibilities as Minister. It is an essential part of both the process of reconciliation and the Government's response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

The reconciliation process emphasises education as a central and essential concern. As the Bill supported unanimously in both houses of Parliament, stresses, there is a need to educate all Australians about Aboriginal history and culture and about the reasons for Aboriginal social and economic disadvantage.
The AEP does that through the nationally agreed goal 21, and through the role the policy plays as a framework for the national reconciliation and schooling strategy, which I announced last April.

Initiatives are now under way to ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies have a valued place in the curriculum of Australian schooling and in the professional development of teachers.

The reconciliation process also emphasises a strategic effort throughout this decade to address Aboriginal disadvantage. Aboriginal people are clearly of the view that any attempt to respond to these issues that does not start to meet the education needs of their community will not be able to succeed. I share that view and I am pleased that the AEP provides a national policy framework for addressing that concern.

The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody called for responses from government to address the underlying causes of the Aboriginal imprisonment rates. Education was one area that it emphasised and the AEP provides a model for the cooperative arrangements that it had in mind.

The Commission also emphasised the central importance of Aboriginal people's involvement in decision-making, especially to ensure that their priorities and concerns are reflected in the education of their children. It cited the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness Program (ASSPA) as a positive example in this regard.

Education is central to social change for both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy recognises this and, linked with other key areas of national commitment such as the reconciliation process, is a clear indication of the priority that this Government places on ongoing change and development in the area of Aboriginal affairs.

Although the changes to this legislation are minor and administrative the passage of these amendments provides an opportunity for the Parliament to give a commitment of support to the principles and practices of the AEP as a means of addressing the educational needs of Aboriginal Australians.
