—But what youth unemployment are you budgeting for?

—I explained at some length to the honourable senator that in terms of youth unemployment he uses a misleading figure in his questions. I thought he might have got that point and not bounced back like an indiarubber ball in the knowledge that the figures that he uses are misleading in terms of the total youth unemployment situation. So the honourable senator's supplementary question in relation to that is redundant or irrelevant until we agree on what the appropriate measure of youth unemployment is-and not a small sample, as chosen by him for his own purposes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of Professor Andrzej Stelmachowski, the Marshal or President of the Polish Senate. I might say that he is a good personal friend of mine. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your time in Australia will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Professor Stelmachowski to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!
Professor Stelmachowski thereupon entered the chamber, and was seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to a new product that has been developed by the South Australian Department of Agriculture. This product, which is known as Agri-Dri, dries fruits, timber and paper products. Does the Minister believe that the product could have other applications in Australian industry and earn export dollars for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not always have time to read the Adelaide news in detail. But the article about this matter has been drawn to my attention. Agri-Dri is apparently a product of considerable commercial potential. It has been developed by the South Australian Department of Agriculture for the drying of fruit.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not give a detailed description of the technology. Agri-Dri uses a pump system which achieves a high degree of efficiency and offers great savings in energy. The project has been partially funded by the Electricity Trust of South Australia. I understand several of these machines are in use, not just for drying fruit but also for other food processing production. Not only is the Agri-Dri an alternative to conventional dryers used by rural cooperatives; it can also be a substitute for conventional sun drying used by farmers. The problems of sun drying are substantially reduced by this technology.

I do not believe that the idea has been fully commercialised at this time. Its development is continuing with the aim of improving the efficiency even further. The machines in operation have been custom-made for specific requirements. Other applications may well be identified as development proceeds. Initial production has been for the Australian domestic market. In terms of the question that Senator Maguire asked, it can be said with confidence that there are good export prospects down the track for this technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the ACTU annual conference-which Senator Cook is currently attending and from which he is receiving his marching orders for the year-serious in demanding that future wage increases be based on overseas inflation rates if those rates are higher than Australia's? Will the Government reject this stupid and destructive proposal out of hand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the first part of the question that Senator Cook, as Minister for Industrial Relations, is at the ACTU annual congress receiving his marching orders. In the better days of the Liberal Party when it was in Government and had a wages policy and industrial policy--
—When was that?
—A very long time ago.
—Where is your health policy?

—Senator Kemp, being here a fortnight, interjects about health policy. I thought Senator Kemp was a student of politics. I thought he would have known. He should ask Senator Baume about health policy. I would have thought that that was a very sensitive issue for Senator Kemp to interject about. We learn as we go on and given a few more years in Opposition, Senator Kemp might get to the front bench.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the first part of Senator Parer's question, in those halcyon days when that once great party-as Sir Robert Menzies referred to it-was in government, Liberal Ministers for Industrial Relations would meet with the ACTU and attend the ACTU congress as appropriate.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —All those one-eyed rednecks opposite are psyching themselves up--
—What do you mean `rednecks'?

—I am not referring to Senator Boswell. I am looking at the Liberal Party. That is the last thing I would call Senator Boswell! Those opposite are psyching themselves up into tough positions, knowing that they were weak on all of these issues during their eight years in government.
—Answer the question!

—Senator Parer can interject about these questions. Any proposition which emerges from the ACTU congress will, at the appropriate time, if the ACTU so decides, be communicated to the Government. One always gets questions from this Opposition about likely wage outcomes, about how the wage system is to be in the next year. I have had these questions as long as I have been Leader of the Government in the Senate: what is going to happen? What is the Government going do about wages next year? The brutal fact which the Opposition has to face up to is that this Government has delivered, throughout its history as a government, on wage outcomes.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—In all that hubbub, I pay a tribute to Senator Parer who really was interested in the answer to the question about wage outcomes. We are asked questions about wage outcomes all the time. On wage outcomes, this Government has delivered, as distinct from previous governments.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government position on wage outcomes is contained in its submission to the current review of the wage fixing principles. It talks about a generally accessible wage increase. It says that claims for a general wage increase to protect living standards would need to be assessed against the question of how the new wage system is working. The quality of the agreements reached and the commitment to lower inflation will be key ingredients in these wage outcomes.
I cannot speak for any speeches that were made at the ACTU congress. The ACTU will put a position to the Government in due course and we will consider it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As Senator Button was quite obviously not prepared to reject out of hand this absolutely stupid and destructive proposal to pay wages based on overseas inflation rates when they are greater than they are in Australia, I ask: why is the Government determined, in conjunction with its unelected masters in the ACTU, to consign Australia to Third World status?

—I thought that I might have made it clear even to Senator Parer that I am not prepared to comment about press reports of speeches made at the ACTU congress. In so far as Senator Parer wants to tar the ACTU with a particular brush, he can do so. One day, when he is a pretty old man, he might have to confront some of the issues instead of making noises in here.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. What family support measures are currently provided for members of the Australian Defence Force? How will the results of the first census of ADF families, which was conducted on March 12 this year, be used in the development of future Australian Defence Force family policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1985 Hamilton report, entitled Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses, and the 1988 Cross report, entitled Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force, identified the need for the Australian Defence Force to provide additional family support measures to improve the quality of service life. Since then, a wide range of measures have been taken to improve family support. The creation of the Australian defence family information and liaison staff was a major step in this. Through the ADFILS service, families have access to a toll-free telephone information service which has dealt with more than 10,000 calls. The inquiries, since its establishment in 1989, have been on a wide range of matters to do with service conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: The family support funding program budget for 1991-92 of $1m is distributed nationally in grants of up to $20,000 for play groups, child-care centres, spouse organisations and neighbourhood centres. A further $1m has been allocated under the facilities program to provide for the establishment and capital improvement of child-care centres. Already a number of the centres have been set up at facilities around the country.

The normal posting cycle has been extended from two years to three years to provide greater geographic stability. Where possible, members with school age children are given back-to-back postings in the same locality.

The standard of housing has been upgraded significantly. The Defence Housing Authority, set up in 1987, is half way through a decade-long billion dollar program for constructing and acquiring better quality housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just a dorothy dixer; you might as well send her the answer!

—This is not a dorothy dixer, Senator Newman; it is a question that Senator Zakharov has asked. As the Opposition has asked only one question on defence in the last 14 Question Times, Senator Zakharov probably felt impelled to ask a question in the defence area.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators will appreciate from these remarks, much has been done on the family front in recent years. However, refining family policy is a continuing process. That is why we commissioned the Australian Institute of Family Studies to conduct a census of members and their families in March of this year.

The data provided by the census gives us a very powerful tool to identify whether the needs of service families are being met. Its value lies in its ability to provide quantitative answers to highly specific questions. For example, it can tell us the number of school age children in a particular area, the average age of the serving members at a particular facility and so on.

Assessing and utilising the data is a complex job. The census will be of the most value over the longer term as the results are matched against the national census and, subsequently, ADF family censuses. The data will provide the ADF with firm evidence to back up its submissions to Federal, State and local authorities for access to community facilities. It will allow greater targeting of ADF family needs. The Defence Housing Authority is already using the data to ensure that its married quarters purchasing and construction program matches family requirements.

Later this year the Australian Institute of Family Studies will prepare a detailed technical report which will allow us to focus on areas of greatest need, ensuring that the service and the community gain the maximum benefits from these family support measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button representing the Prime Minister. I ask: is the new federalism policy on the care of the Australian environment being negotiated by the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories or by the Prime Minister? Is the Federal Minister for the Environment involved in the negotiations with the States on this important matter? If not, why not? Does Senator Button agree that the Environment Minister's view on new federalism as presented last Monday evening in the Four Corners program does not accord with that of the Prime Minister? Finally, will the Minister release the fifth draft of the intergovernmental agreement on new federalism so that the people of Australia can judge for themselves what pattern of environmental management is being negotiated between the States and the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Coulter ought to know-but I am not surprised that he does not-these issues are being discussed at the Premiers Conference between the Prime Minister, representing the Federal Government, and the State Premiers, representing the various State governments. The negotiations are conducted at that level. However, in establishing a Commonwealth position, the Environment Minister has an input into what that position will be. I would imagine that the same thing applies at the State level.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the publication of any draft agreement relating to new federalism, I do not know whether there is much point in publishing draft agreements except for the titillation of people such as Senator Coulter. These agreements form the basis for discussion. Until a firmer position is identified by all governments concerned, I do not think that there would be any point in that. The answer to that part of the question is: no, unless after consultation with the Prime Minister it is decided otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am disappointed with the Minister's reply, trivialising such an important issue as indicating that he thinks I am seeking this information simply to achieve some titillation-to use his word. I ask: Will the Minister inform the Senate who, if anybody, in the office of the Minister for the Environment is involved in these negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot inform Senator Coulter of that. Even if I knew the answer, I still would not tell him.
—Good open government!

—Senator Coulter has been a member of this chamber for four or five years. Senator Walters has been here for about 400 years. She is still making the same mistake as Senator Coulter makes, that is, that during Question Time Ministers should say which members of a Minister's staff are responsible for what. That is not a relevant question, and Senator Walters ought to know that. It is a disgraceful Opposition that allows an interjection of that degree of ignorance and, to use a contemporary term, that degree of crassness. This Opposition is so crass as to interject with comments like that.

ANSWER.PARA: Even if I knew the answer to Senator Coulter's question, I would not tell him, because it is none of my business and, quite frankly, it is none of his, either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Collins as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Will the Minister advise what impact a proposed goods and services tax would have on the economy of northern Australia in general and the vital tourism industry in particular?
—Cheaper freight!
—Cheaper freight? Is the Minister aware of media reports that the proposed tax will be struck at a rate of 12.5 per cent? Will the Minister comment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were a member of the Opposition I would be laughing on the other side of my face, because my source for what I am about to say is the coalition candidate for the House of Representatives seat in the Northern Territory, Mr Arthur Palmer, who is mentioned in today's newspapers. One headline in today's Herald-Sun reads `12.5% Tax Tip'. The article states:

ANSWER.PARA: Hewson, Fischer `gave me GST details'
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated by the interjections from Opposition members about what GST will give us. They say it will give us cheap freight. The article in the Herald-Sun states:

ANSWER.PARA: While Opposition backbenchers had been given few details of the tax, Mr Palmer said he had been well briefed-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you make it 42 per cent?
—You probably will!
—Senator Faulkner, how about you jump in when I start to falter!
—Order! Senator Collins will resume his seat. There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber.
—Opposition members were interjecting that GST will give us cheap freight. The article states:

ANSWER.PARA: While Opposition backbenchers had been given few details of the tax, Mr Palmer said he had been well briefed because the tax will have its biggest impact in the NT, where all freight costs will be lifted by the tax.
That is absolutely true, of course, as Senator Tambling knows. According to that article, Mr Palmer said:
I haven't got a crystal ball, I have been told . . . I had quite good briefings, particularly by Fischer and Hewson.

I have known for 10 years that Arthur Palmer is a complete drop kick, but now Mr Fischer and Dr Hewson know it as well. I did try to tell the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory what a total drop kick he had preselected for the seat because, until last year, I think, Arthur Palmer was a Labor Party supporter for 10 years. I was always terrified that he was going to nominate for preselection for a seat. As president of the Party, I told him that it would be over my dead body if he ever did.

Mr Palmer has claimed publicly that Dr Hewson and Mr Fischer have told him that this tax will be 12.5 per cent. As all honourable senators know-and those from northern Australia should know-one of the most vital industries for northern Australia, and certainly for the Northern Territory, is tourism.

Recently, the Australian Tourism Industry Association expressed grave concern about the impact of a goods and services tax. I commend to honourable senators from north Queensland the recent paper on the impact of such a tax entitled The impact of a goods and services tax (GST) on the Australian tourism industry. In that paper, Mr Peter O'Clery said that his association was concerned about the possibility that GST might be struck at a rate of 12.5 per cent to 15 per cent. Mr O'Clery's paper said that if this happened `we would have a disaster on our hands in the Australian tourist industry'. Recently, ATIA has had first hand discussions with the tourism industry in New Zealand and Canada, which have both suffered greatly as a result of the imposition of a GST.

ATIA believes that a GST would have a more severe impact on overall tourism in Australia than it had in New Zealand-and it will-and would weaken the fragile edge of the domestic market which has been won from the Hawke Government's deregulation of domestic aviation. It is the assessment of ATIA that this disastrous impact will be evident on any consumption tax above 7 per cent. I say again that this would be a disaster for northern Australia, because tourism alone is worth $400m to the Northern Territory, which is 8 per cent of the gross domestic product of the Northern Territory.

In a separate study for the ATIA, the Australian Tourist Commission has estimated that there would be a 15 per cent price increase applied under a consumption tax; that the proposed annual loss to Australia would be 125,000 visitors from Japan, Germany, Britain, New Zealand and the United States of America; and that the loss of export income from these destinations would be $250m a year. Those estimates come from the tourist industry. It is hardly surprising that it makes such claims. I have had a look at the list and I understand-maybe I am wrong-that there is no representative from northern Australia in the coalition on the coalition's committee on consumption tax; it is hardly surprising that there is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister ought to be aware that 60 per cent of New South Wales is presently drought affected. He also may be aware that the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, the Hon. Ian Armstrong-a colleague of mine-offered $5m some four months ago for drought funding under part B of the rural adjustment scheme on the basis that it be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government. Despite letters to the former and current Ministers for Primary Industries and Energy and verbal assurances from both those Ministers, to date there has been no response. When can the New South Wales Minister, and indeed drought affected farmers in New South Wales who are financially strapped, expect a reply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is: in October. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided me with a response. The Government is conscious of the problems being experienced by the many farmers who have been affected by the current dry conditions. Many of these farmers have also been affected by the downturn in commodity prices. The rural adjustment scheme is the Commonwealth's main instrument for providing support to farmers in financial difficulty.

ANSWER.PARA: Under part B of the scheme, assistance is in the form of interest rate subsidies provided to farmers to enable them to obtain carry-on finance. Farmers affected by drought may be eligible for assistance under this provision. The farmers seeking assistance should approach the relevant State authorities responsible for the administration of RAS.

Commonwealth funding for the rural adjustment scheme has been increased to $160m in 1991-92 and $13.6m will be provided for carry-on assistance which requires matching funding from State governments. Funding of the scheme will be reviewed in October, including an assessment of the need for additional funding for drought relief assistance. The Commonwealth and the States have agreed to set up a working party to consider outstanding issues in relation to drought where the matter raised by Senator Brownhill will be considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware that 103 additional schools have been placed on the list of schools designated for assistance under the country areas program in New South Wales this year? I ask whether the Minister is also aware that the Parliamentary Secretary to the New South Wales Minister for School Education and Youth Affairs, Mr Richard Bull, in a letter to a Mrs Best of Gulargambone, New South Wales, in regard to the CAP stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The additional 103 schools added throughout the state is in response to the Federal Department of Education insisting that these schools be incorporated, so that the level of funding that is, on a per capita basis, be somewhat equal to the level of funding in other states.
Would the Minister advise the chamber as to the truth of these statements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first part of Senator West's question, the answer is yes, I am aware that 103 additional schools have been placed on the list. I am aware of the letter from Mr Bull. I have been asked whether these statements are true. Unfortunately, they are not. The real situation is that under the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training does in fact have responsibility for determining variations to existing prescribed country areas eligible to receive available funding under the country areas program. That is a matter of law.

ANSWER.PARA: However, this declaration is made on the basis of recommendations received from the State Minister of education-and in New South Wales that is the Hon. Virginia Chadwick. This situation recognises that, as State and Territory governments have the primary responsibility for education, State education ministries are responsible for the detailed administration of the Commonwealth country areas program, including of course that most basic aspect: the definition of prescribed country areas.

I understand that the 1991 variations to the prescribed country areas program in New South Wales were made following a review of the operation of the program carried out by the New South Wales Department of School Education in 1990. As a result of this particular review, the boundaries of the prescribed country areas were altered to include the extra 103 additional schools. On Mrs Chadwick's advice, the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training declared the prescribed country areas for New South Wales on 9 April 1991, which included those 103 additional schools.

Mr Bull's statement that the addition of those schools to the list was at the insistence of the Federal Government is therefore entirely untrue. It is part of a dishonest and divisive campaign in New South Wales, which seems to be being run by Mr Bull. It is dishonest in that the basic element of it is untrue; dishonest also in that he claims that some larger schools have been included and some smaller isolated schools have not because of the action of the Federal Government.

The other aspect of this particular campaign that I think is totally objectionable and totally offensive is that Mr Bull in his correspondence-which, as I say, seems to be part of an orchestrated campaign-is running a very divisive agenda. In the second last paragraph of his correspondence, he says to this particular person:
. . . each region has a committee that allocates the C.A.P. funds to the schools depending on submissions put to those committees.
He goes on to say:

There is no reason why some of the isolated schools on the program cannot still retain all or most of their funding regardless of larger schools coming on to the programme. This will be a decision for the local committee.
What he is essentially doing is dividing one school in the country against another. That is totally irresponsible, totally divisive and totally dishonest. It should not be tolerated.

The Federal Government has provided $3.3m to New South Wales under this country areas program in 1991. As we do not run schools, we are happy to leave the detailed administration of the program, including the definition of prescribed areas, to the State Government. However, this sort of dishonesty has to be exposed; this sort of divisiveness has to be rejected. It is unfortunate that, while the opportunity for greater flexibility in Commonwealth-State relations is being fostered by the Special Premiers Conference, these relations are in no way helped by false claims about the Commonwealth's requirements as to our programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just ask the Minister to table the papers he has been quoting from.
—That is a matter for the Minister.
—The one document which is public and not part of my notes is the letter from Mr Bull to Mrs Best. I am happy to table that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs. I refer the Minister to the bankruptcy figures for the year ended 1991 which show that bankruptcies have increased from 8,552 last year to 12,991 this year, an increase of 51 per cent, and to the corporate insolvency figures which show that insolvencies have increased from 7,394 in 1990 to 8,567 in 1991, an increase of 15.8 per cent-a total in business insolvencies and bankruptcies of 22,267, an increase of 38.9 per cent on last year. Can the Minister offer any explanation why his Government, and he in particular, allowed this horrendous situation to happen to the small business and business sectors? Does he believe his Government's policies are on track.
—Ha, ha!
—I am glad it amuses the Government. It certainly does not amuse the small business people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I acknowledge the fact of the publication of the statistics referred to by Senator Boswell by the Australian Securities Commission. The practice of publishing these statistics has not been a longstanding one. This is the ASC's initial release of corporate insolvency statistics and it intends to release both monthly and aggregate quarterly statistics on an ongoing basis in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The regular release of corporate insolvency statistics by the ASC will supplement the release of quarterly personal bankruptcy statistics by my colleague Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Of course I do not take any comfort in the release of these figures which Senator Boswell has referred to. I suppose that the point of the question is that Senator Boswell seeks to implicate the Government in these figures.
—Members opposite are the Government; I presume they are responsible for policy.
—Yes--

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr President, on a point of order: apart from anything else, this is a very serious question on a serious subject, and to have the other side rolling in the aisles during Question Time--
—Order! I have asked for order three times. This is a fault that occurs on both sides of the chamber, depending on who is listening to the broadcast on different days. If it continues--
—Rubbish, I have never seen it happen before.
—It is not rubbish. If it continues I will take the broadcasting facility away.

—I had made two points: this is the first time the statistics have been published by the ASC; and the other figures on bankruptcy are released by Senator Tate. The increase of 20 per cent in insolvencies is not encouraging. We always have a high level of small business failures of one kind or another in Australia. Undoubtedly, that has increased as a result of the circumstances of the recession. As the recession recedes, I believe that there will be an improvement in those figures; I certainly hope so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his understatement. I am well aware that this is the first time that the Australian Securities Commission has put these figures out. That was not the thrust of my question. My question relates to the fact that over 22,000 businesses went broke last year. The thrust of my question is: what will the Government do about it? Is there any hope for the future? Can the Minister give to small business any message as to whether they should surrender or should keep going and try to fight their way out of the recession?

—In the latter part of my answer, I referred to my hope and belief that as the recession receded these figures would improve. I note that in the supplementary question Senator Boswell seeks to make the same point he made in the introductory question. Senator Boswell asked me whether I should invite small business to surrender. I never invite anybody to surrender; I invite people to look to the future with hope. I did that in the earlier answer to the question.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the rise in the number of unemployed Australians by another 8,600 to the new high of 840,500, announced today and mentioned earlier in the chamber, and to the statement by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, that the Government was working on measures to create `a supportive environment for traded goods and services, so that we can encourage an increase in job opportunities in that sector'. I ask the Minister: what are the measurements that the Government is considering? How many jobs will they create and when will the Government introduce them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those remarks were made by my colleague Mr Dawkins at 12.30 p.m. today. Not having had foresight of Senator Spindler's question-although I try-I have not discussed with him what he had in mind. The unemployment difficulties and problems that we have at the present time will largely and only ultimately be resolved by wealth creation and growth opportunities in employment in the private sector
—Come on, John! Perk up.
—I am sorry. I nearly perked up several times last night, but that had nothing to do with--
—No, no-perking up is what you need to do.

—Those opposite ought to be ashamed of themselves coming in here and condoning interjections of that kind. Who do those opposite think they are? They are a sort of disorganised rabble over there; it is disgraceful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find the Minister's answer extremely disappointing. He is representing the Treasurer. The question was: what measures will the Government take? Mr Dawkins referred to measures that the Government will take. What will the Government do to encourage private industry and to encourage productive investment and exports? I believe that the Treasurer and his representative in this chamber--
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.
—They owe it to one million unemployed to indicate at least when some information on these measures will be available.
—The question did not in fact refer to private industry. One of the sad things about questions from the Australian Democrats is that their questions never do refer to private industry.
—Oh, come on!
—What is Senator Coulter interjecting about? His only interest in life is imposing inhibitions on private investment in a whole range of areas.
—Look who's talking.

—I ask Senator Panizza whether that is right or wrong. Macro-economic conditions will be prime in determining the investment behaviour of the private sector. We have been through that discussion in the Budget debates and so on. If Senator Spindler is disappointed with my answer, all I was saying in that answer was, `Watch this space and wait for the next one when the Government has appropriate responses to give him'.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister explain why, in the 18 months since Mr Hawke told the women of Australia that he was committed to reducing the tragic loss of life of more than 2,300 women each year and the personal anguish associated with breast cancer, only $1m has been spent on the national program for the early detection of breast cancer instead of the $64m over three years promised by Mr Hawke at the last election? Is this negligent, tragic lack of urgency over such a lifesaving program simply an indication of the Prime Minister's cynical disregard of Australian women until he wants to engage in crass politics to woo their votes at election time?

—I do not have a precise answer to that question. I anticipate that some of these programs which involve large amounts of expenditure take some time to gear up. I do not think we can measure the effects and responses to particular expenditures and say that if we spent $64m we will achieve this result and if we spend less we will achieve--
—Three years-$64m; 18 months-$1m.

—I am just making the point that I anticipate that this is a program which, like many others, has to be geared up. Let me obtain a detailed answer from the Prime Minister's office and provide it to Senator Newman as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister provide details about the activities of the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation and, in particular, its role in providing opportunities for farmers to diversify into alternative enterprises?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided me with the following response. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What action is the Government taking to alleviate growing concern about the accuracy of claims regarding the environmental benefits of a wide range of consumer products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most honourable senators would agree that, these days, environmentally conscious Australians will, if the prices of goods are more or less equal, purchase those which do the least possible damage to the environment. ANSWER.PARA: It is a difficult matter to judge, in my view, because one may be talking not only of the product but also of the manufacturing or agricultural process which led to the product being available in the marketplace. There is the question of the wrapping or the container in which the product is marketed and how that is disposed of. There is some difficulty with making environmentally friendly claims, but they are made and it is extremely important that consumers feel confident that such claims are not misleading or deceptive.

For that reason, the Trade Practices Commission has been provided with substantial funds in this Budget, first of all to provide for a guideline to be issued to manufacturers, retailers and so on, so that they can try to avoid the perils of not complying with those sections of the Trade Practice Act which deal with misleading and deceptive advertising. All would agree that, when people can exercise their power in the marketplace to ensure that their purchasing is in harmony with their desire to undertake an environmentally friendly decision, we need to ensure that the Trade Practices Commission has the power and the capacity to ensure that any claims which are misleading or deceptive are dealt with by the courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's appalling youth unemployment figures have generated a new style of creative accounting by Senator Button, who somehow has sought to demonstrate to the chamber that a 29 per cent unemployment rate-the worst recorded in Australia; it may have been worse during the Depression, but we do not know what the figures are-is somehow inconsequential because he has established what proportion of the total population that is. If Senator Button applied the same criteria to the unemployment rate of people over 65, he would also get a quaint figure; in other words, the criteria he is using are absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to demonstrate just how bad the real unemployment figures are because they are far worse than the 29 per cent that Senator Button pretends does not exist. I mention to Senator Button that his Government has instituted a procedure which enables young people aged between 15 and 19 years to stay at school. I must say that I commend aspects of that program because it gives many young people an opportunity to improve their options. However, a very large proportion of those people are being paid to get out of the dole queues. When we look at the jobs for young people that are disappearing, we see exactly how many people are unemployed around Australia.

Let us get a feeling of the number of people who are being paid to stay out of the dole queues. In July, there were 100,000-odd young persons under the age of 20 years receiving unemployment benefit of one kind or another. Between January and May of this year, the average number of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds receiving Austudy was 241,000-2 1/2 times as many people. I concede that a large number of them are people who would have sought Austudy anyway, but surely Senator Button must concede that a large proportion of those 241,000 young Australians are back at school because they could not get a job. That is easily demonstrated.

There was an increase in youth employment in recent years before the depths of recession. The figure went up from about 410,000 to 430,000 a couple of years ago and then suddenly collapsed. It is during this collapse of the last two years that people who cannot find jobs have been paid to go back to school and that hides the real impact of youth unemployment. The figures are there, they are evident, and any nonsense that Senator Button comes out with cannot hide the realities. We can see this.

The collapse in the last couple of years in the number of young Australians holding jobs indicates this huge level of hidden unemployment because the job losses have not been offset or accounted for by anything like matching increases in unemployment. On the contrary: there has been a loss of 152,000 jobs for young people in the last two years, and this has resulted in a rise of only about one-quarter of that number in the unemployment level. It has gone up by about 40,000 instead of 152,000 job losses.

Where are the other 112,000 young Australians who simply disappeared from the unemployment figures? There has been a fall in the 15-year-old to 19-year-old population of something like 50,000 over that time, but this still leaves more than 60,000 young Australians unaccounted for, particularly by Senator Button's creative accounting. He is only dealing with people, so maybe he does not take it too seriously. The bulk of the 62,000 young Australians either returned to school funded by Austudy as an alternative to joining the unemployment queues or simply withdrew from the work force, because the rate of participation of young people has collapsed. It has gone from over 60 per cent to around 52 per cent or 53 per cent.

If my analysis is correct-which the numbers clearly indicate-then the real full time youth unemployment level is probably around 190,000 in Australia, which gives an appalling unemployment rate of just under 40 per cent for those seeking full time work. On top of this, there is clear evidence of mounting underemployment as the proportion of the total youth work force made up of full time employees has slumped over the past decade from 68 per cent to only 41 per cent, while part time workers have more than doubled from 17 per cent to 37 per cent. As 236,000 full time youth jobs have disappeared-70 per cent of these in the last two years-they have been only partly replaced by 137,000 extra part time jobs.

The reality is-and nothing Senator Button says can escape this fact-that there has never been such a bleak outlook for employment for young Australians as part of this engineered recession since the Great Depression. The problem is that this Government does not know what the level or total of youth unemployment will reach. We have asked over and over what the Budget figures, which indicate a 10 3/4 three quarters per cent total unemployment rate, will reach.

We have yet to find out what this Government is budgeting for in terms of youth unemployment. We presume it knows but simply does not want to tell us because the figures would be so horrific-although there is a prospect that it simply does not know. I fear that that may be the situation because clearly it has yet to work out how to resolve the disastrous recession that it deliberately engineered and the disastrous impact on unemployment-not simply youth unemployment but total unemployment in Australia, which has now reached a dismal record once again.

Politicians must focus on this national disaster because nearly one million people are unemployed. As Senator Baume said earlier, something like 152,000 young Australians are lost from the statistics. Even the figures do not show where they have gone.

The long term unemployment problem in Western Australia is my State's biggest problem. It is clearly the result of some of the policies of this Federal Government and some of the policies of the Lawrence, Burke and Dowding Labor governments in Western Australia. Over 38,000 people in Western Australia have not worked for more than six months. This is a very serious problem, because when people are out of work for that long they start to lose self-esteem, confidence, any faith in the future and, indeed, any faith in the very fabric of our society.

Only a few weeks ago, I visited a YMCA shelter for street kids in a suburb called Kelmscott. I spoke to young 14-, 15-= and 16-year-olds who spend their days at the shelter playing pool and ping pong and basically keeping out of trouble. These kids told me about the amphetamine problem in Perth and the fact that people steal videos, cars, television sets, radios, jewellery, purses or whatever they can get to go into Northbridge, around the nightclub districts, and trade these goods for amphetamines. I asked one of these young chaps, `Do you want to get a job? What's your ambition in life?'. He said, `Yes, I would like to be a carpenter'. Another one said, `Yes, I would like to be a motorbike mechanic'. I said, `That's great. What is your longer term ambition once you have a job?'. I use that terribly sad example of youth in Kelmscott in the Federal electorate of Canning, just down the road from my office, to show that there is a new culture in Australia. I conclude by going through some of the more appalling statistics in some of the worst areas of Western Australia. At the unemployment office in Gosnells, just a couple of miles down the road from my office, in the middle of Mr George Gear's electorate of Canning, there has been a 75 per cent increase in the past 12 months. As Senator Vanstone said, it does not matter whether the rate is 10, 11 or 12 per cent; when one faces this situation one is 100 per cent unemployed.

This requires the earnest appreciation of politicians on both sides of the political fence. It requires policy measures, but clearly this Government has shown an inability to implement them. It requires courage and focusing on the achievement of economic growth for Australia so that we can rebuild hope for all these Australians, particularly Western Australians, who find themselves with little hope of finding employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the Hunter in the last year, 17,000 people have lost their jobs. The unemployment rate in the Hunter has risen from 9.9 per cent a year ago to 11.1 per cent today. If honourable senators think that is bad enough, they should think about the rate for the young people. A year ago, 16,500 were in full time employment; today, only 9,500 are in full time employment. Seven thousand of them have lost their jobs. But saddest of all with the young is to look at the figures of the participation rates. A year ago, 64.9 per cent of young people were in the work force; today, that figure has dropped to 57 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The great burden of the unemployment visited upon Australia by the recession has fallen on young people. Just when productive, wealth-creating working lives are supposed to begin, employers have no choice but to put up the shutters. What is the Government doing about this appalling situation? It says that it is worried and concerned. But is it genuinely worried and concerned about the 850,000 people out of work? I remind the Government that that is 850,000 votes it could lose at the next election. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claims:
The present level of unemployment is totally unacceptable as anything like a permanent feature of our society. It is no part of our policy to allow it to continue.

Why did the Government let it begin? It was this Labor Government policy that put 850,000 people out of work by engineering a recession that it said we had to have. Because the Government has no answers, the Prime Minister has promised the ACTU that it will consider a union proposal to relieve Australia's high unemployment rate. The ACTU charter aims to create an extra 125,000 jobs a year.

Why has the Prime Minister given an undertaking to the ACTU to look at its employment proposals? Because the ACTU has warned Mr Hawke to change the jobs policy now or to lose his job. Martin Ferguson, the ACTU President, does not hesitate to blame the Government. He says:

We do not meekly accept the consequences of policies which have produced the current level of unemployment. No section of the community will be more vigilant in ensuring that the federal Labor government keeps to its undertakings . . . that the economic recovery will restore sustained growth and secure employment.
Also, Bill Kelty, Secretary of the ACTU, says:

Australian workers and their unions could bear no blame for the unemployment problem after making substantial sacrifices under the prices and incomes accord. The federal government should adopt a more expansive economic approach balancing growth with continued low inflation.

Other comments have been made recently by Labor supporters who are obviously worried about losing their hold on power or losing their seats. John Halfpenny has said, `Labor will be forced out of office if it does not tackle the crisis'. A Labor backbencher, Laurie Ferguson, says:

Unemployment is finally getting the attention of the ACTU and ministers. I think it's pretty pleasing Bill Kelty and John Button have come out of the sleepy hollow. It's late in the day, but I'm pleased they have both come out in support.
I don't think there is any argument that over the last few years more (help) has been required for unemployment.
This is a Labor government which is not offering any hope to its own members at the next election. But, worst of all, it is not offering any hope to the 850,000 people out of work in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate for any longer than I have to. However, as the Senate will not meet again for another few weeks, I feel that I should say something now about the problems associated with commuter airline services in country New South Wales. I think honourable senators would be, as is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), very well aware of my continued interest in this subject and the wider issue of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: I have given some seven notices of motion on the subject. I have raised the matter no fewer than 13 times in the past three years. I have also issued several media releases on the subject and given countless radio interviews. Indeed, this session alone I have asked two questions of the Minister regarding the problems associated with the third runway at Kingsford-Smith airport and the peak period landing charges, and the problems that that has caused to commuter services in New South Wales.

I have also presented more petitions than any other senator on the questions of peak period surcharges and the third runway for Mascot. The tens of thousands of signatories to those petitions represent a majority of country people who absolutely depend on flights to Sydney to conduct business, to gain access to specialist health services and to visit families.

For two years now the debate as to whether Sydney airport needs a third runway has dragged on. The genuine needs of air travellers have been overridden by sordid little factional squabbles in an effort to save Labor Party seats around Mascot. To keep the story brief, I have been hounding the Minister over the third runway issue and peak period surcharges. I was concerned then, and remain concerned now, that the viability of commuter aircraft and the viability of the country centres that they service would be at risk if the inefficiencies remained and the efficiencies were not put in place at Kingsford-Smith airport. Such efficiencies, of course, include the third runway as a matter of urgency. As I have said, I have been absolutely pushing that for some time.

I was assured, when I raised the matter in February and again in April this year, that the review of the three-month trial period for peak scheduling would be completed by the end of May. The Minister assured me at that time that it was not designed as a revenue raiser but merely as a regulator. It has certainly been an effective traffic regulator. Last week Hazelton Airlines announced that it would cease services to 14 country centres in New South Wales. It cited the peak period surcharge as one of the reasons that those routes had become non-viable.

Not surprisingly, the Minister would not concede that the charges had caused bigger problems or more difficulties than had already been there. He did accept, however, that this year alone Hazelton would have to pay $4.2m in government imposts. I believe that, for an airline the size of Hazelton, that is an excessive amount of money to be absorbed and passed on in fares.

I take the Minister up on one of the answers he gave to me the other day with respect to charges. He said that there was only something like $1.34-I think that was the figure he mentioned-per passenger extra because of the Government-imposed charges. I tell him that for morning and afternoon services Hazelton had to put on $25 per ticket and for night services something like $22 extra per ticket. That is working on 60-odd per cent loading. Obviously, the Minister's figures were a little wrong and out of kilter with respect to the problem it was causing to the airline. The government charges have increased over the last five years to such a degree that in 1986 they represented something like 2 per cent of an average passenger ticket. Today, the charges represent 17.6 per cent or more of an average passenger ticket. How can Hazelton cope with increases of that magnitude and still give the services that it does?

I divert for a moment to say that Hazelton has been one of the top country airlines in Australia. It is a privately owned airline that has gradually built its way up. The fact that it has had to move away from those 14 airports which it was servicing, albeit replaced in some by other people, is to the great discredit of the Government.

The peak period surcharge, I believe, has been one of the big problems. It has been inequitable. Hazelton, of course, using its eight seater or 16 seater planes, pays the same peak period surcharge as a jumbo jet with 300 passengers. Obviously, that must have some bearing on Hazelton's viability, and for the Minister to suggest otherwise is absurd.

The Federal Government demonstrates regularly that it cares little for rural Australia and that it is not prepared to give any sympathetic consideration to the special needs of country commuters. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, should in his commonsense way tell the Government about some of the problems that it is causing to country people.

Obviously, any country town that can boast direct daily flights to Sydney can attract companies looking for decentralisation opportunities or, indeed, government and other public instrumentalities wanting to locate a particular regional headquarters or service in that country town. If a country town does not have regular services going to the city in the morning and coming home at night there is not much value in an air service. In my area, it has been replaced by services that just do not work out. Commuters have to stay overnight in Sydney, for example. It costs them something like another $150 to go on a trip to Sydney, whether it be for health reasons or to visit family.

The decision that has been taken by Hazelton because of these government imposts has resulted in the loss of some 60 jobs within its operations, and job losses in country towns have a much bigger effect than in Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne. The multiplier effect has a devastating impact on the people in those country towns.

For two years I have been trying to warn the Government of the cost of its procrastination on Mascot. I have been fobbed off time and time again with EIS processes, reviews, reports and submissions. It astounds me that in a country like ours we have to go through so many little processes to get a result. The result will be that we need it and the Minister realises that we need it but it will be too late for airlines such as Hazelton.

We have had the ultimate furphy this week with the suggestion that airlines should levy a $5 surcharge on tickets to pay for the insulation of houses in the Mascot area. I think that is the biggest furphy in the world. Under the new proposal for the third runway planes will not fly over any more houses than they do at present. They will fly over a lot of factories before reaching the airport. They will be taking off and landing near the water. That will make it a lot better for the people who live in those areas. All the warnings that I have given over the years about the airport and the need for the third runway have fallen on deaf ears. Now it seems irrelevant because what I said would happen has happened. That has made me feel very sad.

Rural New South Wales is suffering. Country towns are drying up and the forced withdrawal of services by Hazelton, caused by the Federal Government's procrastination, is assisting this drying up process.

This is not the end of the issue. When more time permits, I intend to raise the matter again. I will continue to raise it until either commonsense prevails in the Cabinet and the third runway gets built or we have the next election and the Labor Government, along with those members whose electorates are around Mascot, is thrown out of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak about the tragic unemployment figures that were released today. This situation is the result of what is left of the Labor Party's socialist philosophy-a philosophy of control, regulation, taxation, the taking away of initiative and the destruction of enterprise. That philosophy arose when this Government was in opposition. In February 1983 it adopted the accord on economic policy between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. At that time, I said that the accord document would prove to be a tragedy for this country. And that is what it has proved to be. The implementation of that agreement with the ACTU has led to the tragic unemployment figures that exist today.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not deny that in 1982 the unemployment figures were extraordinarily high. The percentages were probably as high then as they are at the present moment. However, there was a clear reason for that. During the last 18 months or two years of the Fraser Government's term in office, there had been a massive break-out in wages. Certain members of the Australian Labor Party, including then Senator Don Grimes-who, in effect, admitted it in this chamber-urged people in the ACTU and various trade unions to carry out a war of attrition against the Fraser Government by claiming wage increases and going out on strike for no reason whatsoever other than the ultimate objective of getting the Australian Labor Party into office.

Various members of the Australian Labor Party who contributed to that tragedy then became Ministers in the Government. It is a disgrace that they set about destroying the economy of this country. They pushed that situation until ultimately the unemployment figures and the strike rate had reached certain levels. In due course, the people chose the Hawke Government. After the Hawke Government took office, the strike rate fell enormously in accordance with the prior arrangements.

A number of other factors had affected the Fraser Government. There was a worldwide recession that broke shortly after Mr Hawke came to office. There was also an Australia-wide drought, the like of which we had not seen for over 100 years. Shortly after Mr Hawke came to office, that drought broke.

So the unions had achieved their objective. They had got rid of the Fraser Government and achieved enormous wage increases which meant that there was no need for further wage increases. In his last year of office, Mr Fraser introduced a wages freeze. The benefit of that freeze flowed through into 1984 and created an excellent situation for the economic recovery of this country.

That is a short history of why unemployment fell enormously in 1984 and 1985. This fall had nothing to do with any of the policies introduced by the Hawke Government. It was a result of the factors that I have mentioned: the Fraser wages freeze; the world recovery from the worldwide recession; the breaking of the drought; and the fact that, because of the wages freeze, moneys flowed through to business.

Just prior to that election, the Australian Labor Party entered into the accord. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the first page of that accord document, which states, `The party's prime objective is full employment'. In February 1983, the Labor Party and the ACTU entered into an agreement, the prime objective of which was full employment. What do we have in 1991? We have practically 10 per cent unemployment. In fact, the percentage of those who are really seeking work is probably much higher than that. About one million people are unemployed.

Eight years ago the prime objective was to achieve full employment. But after eight years in office, the Government is faced with massive unemployment. Clearly, the accord and those philosophies have failed miserably. That agreement criticises the Fraser Government for its policies. It talks about interventionist policies.

Yet this document has clearly failed. What happened during 1986-87-and Mr Hawke confessed it the other day-was that the Government tried to do something about the unemployment situation by pump priming. Mr Hawke made a comment along the lines that what we did was to borrow our way out of our difficulties. Mr Kerin has now acknowledged that it is necessary for there to be a deregulation of the wage fixing structure. Even Mr Hawke has finally confessed the failure of the accord by his statement at the ACTU Congress yesterday, in which he said-and I quote from the Australian:
. . . that in the move to a more flexible wages system, it was essential to safeguard workers unable to take part in enterprise bargaining immediately.

Mr Hawke was now putting to the ACTU that there would be an across-the-board wage rise. After all the disaster of the across-the-board wage rises that have occurred under this Government, Mr Hawke is now back to saying that there will be another across-the-board wage rise and, in addition, that there will be some sort of flexible bargaining system over and above the general wage rise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you want.

—That is not what we are interested in. That is not what we are talking about at all. We are talking about some sort of flexible bargaining system between the unions and the employers. We are talking about a flexible bargaining system between employees at the workplace and their employers-the sort of thing that has worked with SPC, not the sort of nonsense that those opposite go on about. But what I find absolutely appalling is that Mr Hawke went on-as he is quoted in the newspaper one presumes these are the precise words he used-to say:

SPEECH.PARA: But one thing is clear now: we cannot and will not allow the living standards of one section of the community to fall while others rise . . .

As with the Prime Minister's statement that no child will live in poverty, this is a nonsense. We have 10 per cent unemployment. What is happening to the living standards of the 2,000 people who have lost their jobs in the last month? What has happened to their living standards? Clearly, their living standards have fallen. Here is the Prime Minister of Australia saying, `We will not allow the living standards of one section of the community to fall while others rise. We will give another wage rise to those who are in employment'. It is a nonsense. He is saying, `The fewer and fewer people who are left in full time employment can have a wage rise and that will be across the board. Everyone who remains in employment'-even though it is a smaller group- `will get an across-the-board wage rise because we will not let one section that is in employment get less than the other section that is in employment'. Forget the unemployed!

TALK.START.PARA: —No regard for productivity.

—No regard for productivity and no regard for the unemployed of Australia. The one million people who are unemployed are to be totally ignored because of this foolish statement by this Prime Minister, confronted by the ACTU, the body that he was associated with when it was trying to destroy the Fraser Government. He went on-and I quote from the newspaper-to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government would not ``allow people to fall away and behind and have standards lowered because of their industrial weakness'' . . .

What industrial strengths do the unemployed have? How can they go on strike? How can they demand some wage rise? I find this to be one of the most extraordinary statements I have heard or read from this Prime Minister. He has made some extraordinary statements over his period in office and when he was President of the ACTU. All he is doing when he is talking to the ACTU is saying to them, `We will protect those of you who remain in employment. That is what we will look after. We will make sure that if you have a job your wages will not fall in real levels at all. We will maintain the standard of your wages so long as you have got a job'. The fact that his policies will continue to maintain an unemployment rate of about 10 per cent for the next 12 months or so is just completely ignored. What chance have these people got of getting back into work?

I was told recently about a young lass who graduated from an institution with a qualification in interior decoration. As I understand it, 400 people around Australia graduated with a similar qualification last year, but only five jobs were available in that sort of work. That is the sort of nonsense this Government is going on with. Under its educational policy system, the Government is pushing people into doing courses at institutions, but when they graduate from those courses the poor kids discover that there are no jobs available. They have spent four years of their lives trying to get a qualification and there are no jobs in that industry when they qualify. This Government needs desperately to address its mind to the unemployment problems of the nation and find some reasonable solution to those problems.

—I am actually talking about someone else's contribution, but Senator Brownhill's point is also accurate. The honourable senator may want to admit that some expenditure increases are justified-some of the others to which I am alluding were also justified proposals-but we cannot reduce the total level of expenditure and increase every bit of it. We have the old conservative policy of solving unemployment by getting rid of jobs; of solving inflation by jacking up prices; and of improving workers' living standards by cutting their wages. We cannot have all those, yet that is exactly what we have had.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the GST which will put up prices; we have the cutting of $4.7 billion from outlays which will cost 46,000 jobs; and we have the continuing concern that the 7 1/2 million people who are in employment might get an increase in wages. I think the trends for the recovery are apparent. They are all too painfully slow for those individuals who are unemployed-the human concern that is being expressed is shared by everybody-but, as we find the increase in jobs reflected in this month's figures, the improvements in housing, the improvements in business expectations and the improvements in retail sales, there is no doubt that the signs of the recovery are on the wall.

We all wish it would come more quickly, but what we need now are not policies to cut government spending by $4.7 billion and abolish 46,000 jobs, not policies to introduce a GST to put up prices, and not policies which attack the wages system, but policies to sustain and maintain that recovery which is under way.

However, I do not wish to conclude without acknowledging the validity of the somewhat separate point raised by Senator Brownhill. I do not agree with his views, but I respect the consistency with which he has advocated that position. I am sure I do not need to draw it to the Minister's attention; I am sure he is already well aware of it. Nevertheless, I acknowledge that he has made that point on a continuing basis. I could not allow that series of speeches, which fly directly in the face of the positions of those advocating the policies, to go unremarked.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
