ANSWER.PARA: It is the Australia Council's practice to deal with all applications for grants on the basis of individual merit in competition with other applications received. With regard to project grants, amounts of grants are determined by consideration of the application amount, its relevance to the success of the project and the availability of funds. This practice is common to all areas of Council and is the basis for determining the grant amount in each of the individual cases listed below.
Study of Bookreading and Borrowing in Australia (Policy and Research) $16 000

This was a major research project commissioned by the Australia Council. Tenders were called and the successful tender was Economic Strategies Pty Ltd. The total cost was $50 000 with payment spread over two financial years.

It was a statistical study of the public's use of books in Australia, based on three surveys conducted in 1990, one of book buyers, one of library users and one household survey. It includes information on book reading, book buying, library usage and detailed information about Australian books especially Australian books in public libraries. It also includes summary information about the book industry in Australia.
The resulting report was published by the Australia Council, with some copies distributed free and the balance on sale through D W Thorpe.
Survey of Public Attitudes to the Arts, 1990 (Policy and Research) $20 000

This was a research project commissioned by the Australia Council from the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, University of Melbourne, following the interest shown in two similar studies undertaken by the Institute in 1988 and 1989. The amount was determined on a quote from the Institute which sought competitive quotes for the field work. The Institute was originally chosen by the Council because of its work with a comparable social opinion analysis.

Issues covered in the household survey included: defining the arts, knowledge of the arts, the arts on television, value and uses of the arts, arts occupations and skill, arts occupation and income, funding of the arts. The resulting report was published with detailed appendices.
Australian Tourism Exchange (Advocacy) $42 790

Two amounts initially expended in the areas of Cross Art-Form Activities ($6940) and Music Performance-International Touring ($33 060) were on analysis, found to be more appropriately described as 'Advocacy Travel'. However, a posting error resulted in these two amounts, totalling $40 000, being allocated to the above entry. The amount spent on the Australian Tourism Exchange in 1989-90 was $2790.

The Australia Council allocated $10 000 to provide a display and information on the arts in Australia at the Australian Tourism Exchange, held in Sydney on 22-25 June 1990. Of this amount, $2790 had been expended by the end of the financial year.

The Council's participation at the Exchange focused on the marketability of Australian art, especially Aboriginal art, and the provision of a quick and easy reference guide for the travel industry on capital city arts facilities: 'A Quick Guide to the Australian Arts'.

This is part of a long term strategy for promoting Australian arts and culture as part of the tourism experience. It will result in a much greater awareness of the arts by the tourism industry, as well as increasing the potential for arts organisations to take advantage of tourism markets.
National Ideas Summit (Council Projects) $42 747

In December 1989 the Australia Council agreed to organise and host an 'Ideas Summit' to discuss how new ideas could play a part in producing a more productive and creative Australian nation. Provision was made in the budget for the cost of consultants, venue hire, guest speakers' travel and publications.

The National Ideas Summit was held in the Senate Chamber of Old Parliament House on 26 February 1991. It was attended by 300 participants and observers representing a wide range of disciplines from around Australia. The four sessions explored the roles of scientists, the art, universities and publishing/broadcasting in Australian intellectual and cultural life.

The Summit focused attention on changing the perceptions of Australia from a 'Lucky Country' to a 'Clever Country'. Extensive interest from the general public and the media demonstrated that the issues being raised and discussed were of national concern. Two conference reports were prepared and widely distributed, and following the Summit two forums have been held to explore in more detail some of the issues raised. A major outcome of the Summit has been the establishment of the 'Ideas for Australia' program.
District Council of Murray Bridge (Model Project) $17 250
This grant was awarded under the Townscape Improvement Program of the Australia Council's Design Committee at its meeting in May 1989.

The purpose of this program is to provide grants to local governments and community groups to encourage the use of professional designers on specific projects which improve the amenity and appearance of Australian towns and urban areas.

The Council of Murray Bridge is undertaking a landscape/streetscape program for the central business area of Murray Bridge which enhances the existing historical and local identity of the area. The completed project will act as a stimulus to commercial/business activity. The Council of Murray Bridge has employed design consultants to undertake detailed design work for the implementation of the improvement program based on a 1985 study of the central business district. Design and implementation has been staged over four years, 1989-93.
The Council of Murray Bridge is not due to complete this project until July 1993.
Wyong Shire Council (Model Project) $23 000
This grant was awarded under the Townscape Improvement Program of the Australia Council's Design Committee at its meeting in May 1989.

The purpose of this program is to provide grants to local governments and community groups to encourage the use of professional designers on specific projects which improve the amenity and appearance of Australian towns and urban areas. Wyong Shire Council sought support for the production of designs and design guidelines for a streetscape program along Main Road 335 (road to the coast).

Wyong Shire Council appointed the architectural, planning and landscape firm of Andrews Neil; Fletcher Tysoe Pty Ltd, Landscape Architects; and Forsite EDAW Pty Ltd, Landscape Architects to undertake the following:
- develop concept designs, guidelines and landscape documentation for works within and adjacent to the 11km roadway;
- design guidelines and draft a development control plan for the Killarney Vale Shopping Centre; and
- design street furniture including shelters and signing associated with the road.

The total project involves landscape planning and development guidelines relating to activities within the visual catchment of Main Road 335. The engineering works include a budget of approximately $23 million to upgrade the entire road. Apart from the $23 000 grant, Wyong Council has allowed a $152 000 budget for landscape and planning works associated with the roadworks. Implementation is being spread over four years.
Wyong Shire Council acquitted its grant in July 1990.
Aboriginal Corporation for Homeless and Rehabilitation Community Services (Music) $5 000
This grant was awarded by the Performing Arts Panel of the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in September 1989.
The grant was towards costs of a prison concert program for the period 7 October 1989 to 25 February 1990.
Broome Musicians Aboriginal Corporation (Music) $55 600
This grant was awarded by the Performing Arts Panel of the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in October 1989.
The grant covered part funding of the coordinator's wage, administration costs and administrator's salary for the period 1 January to 30 December 1990.
Lismore CYSS Inc (Aboriginal Drama) $8520
This grant was awarded by the Performing Arts Panel of the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in October 1989.
The grant was provided for a workshop and for script development for one month, February 1990. The workshop took place in Lismore from 14-23 February 1990.
Balgo Warlayirti Artists (Aboriginal Community Arts and Crafts Centre)
This grant was awarded by the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in May 1989 and paid in August 1989.
The grant was for the salary for the arts advisor from 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990.
The second grant of $10 000 awarded in April 1990 and paid in June 1990 covered the salary of the arts advisor and the first instalment of the 1990-91 operating costs.
Northern Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Inc. (Aboriginal Visual Arts Individuals) $35 000
This grant was awarded by the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in December 1989.
The grant was for arts/law operating expenses for major cases of copyright litigation including:
- John Bulunbulun versus Flash T-Shirts;
- Yumbulul versus Reserve Bank ($10 note case); and
- the case of the Milingimbi art collection which was taken to Darwin and sold to the Northern Territory Museum.

The support provided by Northern Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Inc enabled several major cases to be commenced. The Aboriginal Artists Management Association has taken over responsibility for this litigation.
Puatatangi Committee (Aboriginal International Grant) $10 000
This grant was awarded by the Aboriginal Arts Committee at its meeting in October 1989.

The grant was provided towards travel and accommodation costs to enable the bands Yothu Yindi, Coloured Stone and Syvana Doolan to attend the Puatatangi Music Festival in New Zealand between 1 February and 1 March 1990.
Boat Harbour Beach Surf Life Saving Club (Community Access and Touring) $12 440
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in November 1989.

The grant was provided towards the costs of a tour of the north west and west coast of Tasmania by the comedy cabaret company 'Legs on the Wall'. 'Legs on the Wall' is an innovative performance company which utilises physical skills and circus techniques to convey their unique message. Using comic routines and gymnastics, Legs' highly skilled team of four tours to schools, community venues and outdoor events bringing their original performances to audiences across Australia.

The company performed on beaches, in paddocks, streets, surf clubs and local theatres and at special events (such as National Clean-up Day). The venues and events ensured a wide range of audiences. Performances were accompanied by a program to encourage care for the environment.
Building Workers' Industrial Union (Performance Project) $24 487
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in May 1990.
The grant was for a musical theatre production by Sidetrack Theatre based on labour market deregulation.

The result, 'The Serpent's Contract', was a multilingual production performed to some 8000 building workers on sites throughout Sydney, before 400 people at the Teachers Federation, and by the invitation of the Evatt Foundation, at the International Labour Movement Conference. 'The Serpent's Contract' was said to have been remarkable in that it communicated a complex issue to the broadest possible cross section of the workforce in the building industry. It also prompted important media coverage.
Nervus Wrex Inc (Performance Project) $10 000
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in November 1990.
The grant was provided towards the costs of preparing and presenting a community cabaret revue about local environment issues.
The project has not yet been completed.
Next Wave Festival (Performance Project) $22 000
These grants were awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meetings in May and November 1989.
Two grants were made towards the costs of a series of youth festivals in regional Victoria, $12 000 in 1989 and $10 000 in 1990.

The grants enabled young people from East Gippsland, Hamilton, Colac, Bendigo and Melton (1989) and from Ballarat, Bay City, Dandenong, Hamilton and Sale (1990) to participate in a variety of arts activities with professional artists. Activities included group-devised youth theatre pieces, song writing projects and silk-screen printing. Some pieces were performed locally and in neighbouring towns.
Nautilus Scuba Club (Visual Arts Craft Environment Project) $8000
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in May 1989.

The program, 'Mangrove Discovery Cycle' (which is still running), consists of a series of environmental arts activities for school children, parents and teachers, inspired by an appreciation of the mangroves. The activities are being run by Donna Toussaint (a textile artist), Jeff Turpin (a musician), Miriam Torzille (a dancer), Jeanie Adams (a writer) and Alison Bird (a marine biologist and musician).
This grant enables people of all ages to participate in a variety of arts activities with professional artists. It also stimulates interest in environmental issues.
Tenants' Union of Queensland (Visual Arts Craft and Environment Project) $13 739
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in May 1989.

This was a poster/calendar project for inner city residents. Two artists, Robyn McDonald and Christopher Stannard, worked with inner-city groups to produce 12 posters and a 1990 calendar concerning housing issues. The project attracted funding support from several other sources.
The project culminated in an exhibition in Gallery 4 of the Metro Arts building which ran for two weeks.
Another Planet Posters Inc (Non-Performance Group Program) $32 000
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meeting in November 1989.

The grant was provided towards the costs of the annual program of this community access visual arts organisation. The organisation resources individuals and groups, locally and regionally, with a range of services, including silk-screen, fabric printing and computer graphics.
The grant enabled members of the community to participate in a variety of arts activities.
Beale Hawkes Perrier Pty Ltd (Resource Development - Field Initiated) $27 605
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community Cultural Development Committee at its meetings in May 1989 ($23 029) and December 1989 ($4576).

The grant was for research into community theatre and for the organisation of a national seminar on community theatre. The research paper examined the history of community theatre and major contemporary issues, including content of plays, the skill level of the professional people involved and the structure of the main community theatre groups. This paper was then used as the basis for the agenda for the national seminar.
The seminar took place in Adelaide in February 1990 and was attended by approximately 70 representatives from all States and Territories.
Icy Tea - Inala Community Theatre (Performance Based Organiser) $38 000
This grant was awarded by the Grants Committee of the Community cultural Development Committee at its meeting in November 1989.
The grant was provided towards the costs of a co-ordinator and annual program for this community theatre organisation, which targets women, youth and Aborigines.
During the year, workshops for local people were conducted and a number of productions, based upon health and community issues, were performed. A tour of North Queensland was also undertaken.
Service for the Treatment and Rehabilitation of Torture and Trauma (STARTTS) (Literature Community Residencies) $2271

This grant was awarded by the Literature Board at its meeting in May 1989. The sum of $2271 was for payment to the writer associated with this Writer-in-Community project from 1 July 1989 to 1 September 1989. The nominated writer was Jennifer Maiden, a lecturer in creative writing and a writer.

Two series of workshops were conducted assisting people of different ethnic backgrounds to record their experiences of torture in writing. These writings/stories were to form the basis of a booklet intended to educate the non-refugee community about the experiences of people who had suffered such trauma, and was to be developed into a book at a later stage. The languages represented by the participating communities in inner, northern and western Sydney included Tamil, Lao, Vietnamese, Khmer, Latin American Spanish, Iranian and Afghani.

The work initiated by Ms Maiden is still continuing. Five chapters of the book have been completed, and additional chapters are now in the process of preparation. Counsellors, group workers and community development workers have carried on the work and will complete the project using the work methods established by Ms Maiden.
d'Alpuget, Blanche (Literary Fellowship) $30 000
This Fellowship was awarded by the Individual Writers' Grants Assessment Committee of the Literature Board at its meeting in September 1988.

Blanche d'Alpuget was granted a two-year Category A Fellowship for the calendar years 1989 to 1990. A Category A Fellowship is intended to provide a living allowance for writers of substantial achievement who have had at least three major works published or performed. The Committee considered 94 applications for Category A Fellowships and awarded 27, including Ms d'Alpuget's.
The Fellowship was awarded to allow Ms d'Alpuget to write a novel set in Canberra. She is currently still working on the novel.

This grant was awarded by the Dance Committee of the Performing Arts Board at its meeting in September 1989.

Angie Potsche creates and performs dance works incorporating a range of influences including trapeze, mime and the visual arts. The project undertaken was a solo dance performance for a four-night season on 5, 6, 7 and 8 April 1990 at Extensions, Carlton, Victoria.
Cramphorn, Rex (Drama - Creative Development Project) $40 129

The program undertaken was a five-week Creative Development project to incorporate South East Asian influences into a presentation of 'The Tempest'. This was a collaborative activity undertaken between a director, dramaturg, choreographer, Gamelan teacher and seven actors.

The work resulted in a 'work-in-progress' showing at Sydney University in early 1991. A subsequent Performance Project application to extend this work was submitted to the Australia Council, but it was not approved because the funds were not available.
King, Peter (Drama - Performance Project) $45 000
At its meeting in March 1990 the Drama Committee of the Performing Arts Board considered Peter King's original request of $57 634. The sum of $45 000 was approved for the project.

Peter King and his company, 'Going Through Stages', developed a new work under the title 'Axes Edge'. This was a performance piece creating new theatrics from a juxtaposition of architectural, visual art, musical, dance and political themes. The company works in a non- traditional form incorporating movement and dance.
The work was performed at the Anthill Theatre, South Melbourne, from 24 July to 11 August 1990.
Academy of Indian Music and Cultural Studies (Music Performance Project) $2000

The applicant requested $3090 for three projects. The Music Performance Committee of the Performing Arts Board at its meeting in March 1990 funded two of the three projects. The $2000 covered the deficit on the two projects. (The third project was not perceived to be competitive with other applications received.)

The program undertaken was a series of 14 concerts featuring Indian musicians of the Academy of Indian Music and Cultural Studies. In addition, the project stimulated interest in the Indian Classical artform.
Union of Australian Turkish Workers (Music Performance Project) $3000

The applicant applied for $3695 being the expected deficit for performances in Melbourne, Mildura and Sydney. At its meeting in March 1990 the Music Performance Committee of the Performing Arts Board granted $3000 as a contribution towards costs of the Melbourne performance.

The program undertaken was a performance in Melbourne of Turkish and Kurdish music involving 10 local Australian-Turkish musicians and one international artist, Abuzer Karatioc. In addition, the project stimulated interest in Australian-Turkish music.
Buckley, Brad (Overseas Development Studio Stipend) $30 000

Brad Buckley was one of nine artists short- listed for a 1990 Overseas Fellowship Residency at the Institute for Contemporary Art (ICA), New York, by the Professional Development of Artists Committee of the Visual Arts/Craft Board in February 1990. The short-list was forwarded to the ICA where its own assessment committee selected Brad Buckley for the residency.

The amount paid to Brad Buckley is the standard level ($30 000) set by the Visual Arts/Craft Board for all its Fellowships. Fellowship grants seek to give support to established artists with a substantial record of professional activity and achievement, including at least ten years of independent practice. The amount is set at a rate intended to allow recipients to have twelve months away from the pressures of earning a living in order to concentrate on the development of their art practice. In the case of Overseas Fellowship Residencies, the Fellowship takes the form of a stipend which accompanies a year's residency at one of the Board's overseas studios. The amount is set at comparable levels to Fellowships offered by the Australia Council's other Boards and Committees.

The ICA is a centre for contemporary artists with studios for fifty artists who are funded by the governments of their own countries (eg Australia, United Kingdom, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain and Sweden). The ICA provides studio space for the artists and the Board maintains an apartment for the accommodation of the artists and their families.
Brad Buckley used the studio for the period 3 September 1990 to 4 August 1991 to develop his work as a sculptor and installation artist.
Brad Buckley has just completed his residency at the ICA.

While there, his intention is to develop his work as a sculptor within the German context; meet and communicate with German and other international artists; and work in three dimensional collage and construction using materials gathered within the local environment
